chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1:1
verses.text: Extant Works and Fragments of Hippolytus: Exegetical.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1:2
verses.text: Fragments from Commentaries on Various Books of Scripture.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1:3
verses.text: On the HexaÃ«meron, Or Six Days' Work.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1:4
verses.text: Now these things we are under the necessity of setting forth at length, in order to disprove the supposition of others.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1:5
verses.text: For some choose to maintain that paradise is in heaven, and forms no part of the system of creation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1:6
verses.text: But since we see with our eyes the rivers that go forth from it which are open, indeed, even in our day, to the inspection of any who choose, let every one conclude from this that it did not belong to heaven, but was in reality planted in the created system.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 1:7
verses.text: And, in truth, it is a locality in the east, and a place select.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:1
verses.text: On Genesis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:2
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:4
verses.text: And it was evening, and it was morning, one day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:5
verses.text: Hippolytus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:6
verses.text: He did not say "night and day," but "one day," with reference to the name of the light.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:7
verses.text: He did not say the "first day;" for if he had said the "first" day, he would also have had to say that the "second" day was made.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:8
verses.text: But it was right to speak not of the "first day," but of "one day," in order that by saying "one," he might show that it returns on its orbit and, while it remains one, makes up the week.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:9
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:10
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:11
verses.text: And God said, Let there be a firmament in the midst of the water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:12
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:13
verses.text: On the first day God made what He made out of nothing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:14
verses.text: But on the other days He did not make out of nothing, but out of what He had made on the first day, by moulding it according to His pleasure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:15
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:16
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:17
Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:18
verses.text: And let it divide between water and water: and it was so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:19
verses.text: And God made the firmament; and God divided between the water which was under the firmament, and the water above the firmament: and it was so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:20
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:21
verses.text: As the excessive volume of water bore along over the face of the earth, the earth was by reason thereof "invisible" and "formless".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:22
verses.text: When the Lord of all designed to make the invisible visible, He fixed then a third part of the waters in the midst; and another third part He set by itself on high, raising it together with the firmament by His own power; and the remaining third He left beneath, for the use and benefit of men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:23
verses.text: Now at this point we have an asterisk.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:24
verses.text: The words are found in the Hebrew, but do not occur in the Septuagint.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:25
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:26
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:27
verses.text: And they heard the voice of the Lord God walking in the garden at even.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:28
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:29
verses.text: Rather they discerned the approach of the Lord by a certain breeze.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:30
verses.text: As soon, therefore, as they had sinned, God appeared to them, producing consciousness of their sin, and calling them to repentance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:31
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:32
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:33
verses.text: Reuben, my first-born, thou art my strength, and the first of my children; hard to bear with, and hard and self-willed: thou hast waxed wanton as water; boil not over.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:34
verses.text: Aquila.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:35
verses.text: Reuben, my first-born, thou art my strength, and the sum of my sorrow: excelling in dignity and excelling in might: thou hast been insensate as water; excel not.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:36
verses.text: Symmachus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:37
verses.text: Reuben, my first-born, and beginning of my pain: above measure grasping, and above measure hot as water, thou shalt not more excel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:38
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:39
verses.text: For there was a great display of strength made by God in behalf of His first-born people from Egypt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:40
verses.text: For in very many ways was the land of the Egyptians chastised.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:41
verses.text: That first people of the circumcision is meant by "my strength, and the first of my children:"  even as God gave the promise to Abraham and to his seed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:42
verses.text: But "hard to bear with," because the people hardened itself against the obedience of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:43
verses.text: And "hard, self-willed," because it was not only hard against the obedience of God, but also self-willed so as to set upon the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:44
verses.text: "Thou hast waxed wanton," because in the instance of our Lord Jesus Christ the people waxed wanton against the Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:45
verses.text: But "boil not over," says the Spirit, by way of comfort, that it might not, by boiling utterly over, be spilt abroad,âgiving it hope of salvation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:46
verses.text: For what has boiled over and been spilt is lost.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:47
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:48
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:49
verses.text: For thou wentest up to thy father's bed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:50
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:51
verses.text: First he mentions the event,âthat in the last days the people will assault the bed of the Father, that is, the bride, the Church, with intent to corrupt her; which thing, indeed, it does even at this present day, assaulting her by blasphemies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:52
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:53
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:54
verses.text: Simeon and Levi, brethren.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:55
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:56
verses.text: Since from Simeon sprang the scribes, and from Levi the priests.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:57
verses.text: For the scribes and priests fulfilled iniquity of their own choice, and with one mind they slew the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:58
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:59
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:60
verses.text: Simeon and Levi, brethren, fulfilled iniquity of their own choice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:61
verses.text: Into their counsel let not my soul enter, and in their assembly let not my heart contend; for in their anger they slew men, and in their passion they houghed a bull.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:62
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:63
verses.text: This he says regarding the conspiracy into which they were to enter against the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:64
verses.text: And that he means this conspiracy, is evident to us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:65
verses.text: For the blessed David sings, "Rulers have taken counsel together against the Lord," and so forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:66
verses.text: And of this conspiracy the Spirit prophesied, saying, "Let not my soul contend," desiring to draw them off, if possible, so that that future crime might not happen through them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:67
verses.text: "They slew men, and houghed the bull;" by the "strong bull" he means Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:68
verses.text: And "they houghed," since, when He was suspended on the tree, they pierced through His sinews.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:69
verses.text: Again, "in their anger they houghed a bull".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:70
verses.text: And mark the nicety of the expression: for "they slew men, and houghed a bull".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:71
verses.text: For they killed the saints, and they remain dead, awaiting the time of the resurrection.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:72
verses.text: But as a young bull, so to speak, when houghed, sinks down to the ground, such was Christ in submitting voluntarily to the death of the flesh; but He was not overcome of death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:73
verses.text: But though as man He became one of the dead, He remained alive in the nature of divinity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:74
verses.text: For Christ is the bull,âan animal, above all, strong and neat and devoted to sacred use.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:75
verses.text: And the Son is Lord of all power, who did no sin, but rather offered Himself for us, a savour of a sweet smell to His God and Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:76
verses.text: Therefore let those hear who houghed this august bull: "Cursed be their anger, for it was stubborn; and their wrath, for it was hardened".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:77
verses.text: But this people of the Jews dared to boast of houghing the bull: "Our hands shed this".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:78
verses.text: For this is nothing different, I think, from the word of folly: "His blood" (be upon us), and so forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:79
verses.text: Moses recalls the curse against Levi, or, rather converts it into a blessing, on account of the subsequent zeal of the tribe, and of Phinehas in particular, in behalf of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:80
verses.text: But that against Simeon he did not recall.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:81
verses.text: Wherefore it also was fulfilled in deed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:82
verses.text: For Simeon did not obtain an inheritance like the other tribes, for he dwelt in the midst of Judah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:83
verses.text: Yet his tribe was preserved, although it was small in number.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:84
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:85
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:86
verses.text: Binding his foal unto the vine, and his ass's colt to the choice vine,âthe tendril of the vine,âhe will wash his garment in wine, and his clothes in the blood of the grape.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:87
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:88
verses.text: By the "foal" he means the calling of the Gentiles; by the other, that of the circumcision: "one ass," moreover, that is to signify that the two colts are of one faith; in other words, the two callings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:89
verses.text: And one colt is bound to the "vine," and the other to the "vine tendril," which means that the Church of the Gentiles is bound to the Lord, but he who is of the circumcision to the oldness of the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:90
verses.text: "He will wash his garment in wine;" that is, by the Holy Spirit and the word of truth, he will cleanse the flesh, which is meant by the garment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:91
verses.text: And "in the blood of the grape," trodden and giving forth blood, which means the flesh of the Lord, he cleanses the whole calling of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:92
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:93
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:94
verses.text: â His eyes are gladsome with wine, and his teeth white as milk.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:95
verses.text: Zabulun shall dwell by the sea, and he shall be by a haven of ships, and he shall extend to Sidon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:96
verses.text: Issachar desired the good part, resting in the midst of the lots.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:97
verses.text: And seeing that rest was good, and that the land was fat, he set his shoulder to toil, and became a husbandman.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:98
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:99
verses.text: That is, his eyes are brilliant as with the word of truth; for they regard all who believe upon him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:100
verses.text: And his teeth are white as milk;âthat denotes the luminous power of his words: for this reason he calls them white, and compares them to milk, as that which nourishes the flesh and the soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:101
verses.text: And Zabulun is, by interpretation, "fragrance" and "blessing".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:102
verses.text: Then, after something from Cyril:â  Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:103
verses.text: Again, I think, it mystically signifies the sacraments of the New Testament of our Saviour; and the words, "his teeth are white as milk," denote the excellency and purity of the sacramental food.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:104
verses.text: And again, these words, "his teeth are white as milk," we take in the sense that His words give light to those who believe on Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:105
verses.text: And in saying, moreover, that Zabulun will dwell by the sea, he speaks prophetically of his territory as bordering on the sea, and of Israel as mingling with the Gentiles, the two nations being brought as it were into one flock.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:106
verses.text: And this is manifest in the Gospel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:107
verses.text: "The land of Zabulun, and the land of Nephthalim," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:108
verses.text: And you will mark more fully the richness of his lot as having both inland territory and seaboard.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:109
verses.text: "And he is by a haven of ships;" that is, as in a safe anchorage, referring to Christ, the anchor of hope.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:110
verses.text: And this denotes the calling of the Gentilesâthat the grace of Christ shall go forth to the whole earth and sea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:111
verses.text: For he says, "And (he is) by a haven of ships, and shall extend as far as Sidon".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:112
verses.text: And that this is said prophetically of the Church of the Gentiles, is made apparent to us in the Gospel:  "The land of Zabulun, and the land of Nephthalim, by the way of the sea, beyond Jordan, Galilee of the Gentiles; the people which sat in darkness saw great light".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:113
verses.text: In saying, then, that he, namely Zabulun, would inhabit a territory bordering on the sea, he plainly confirmed that, just as if he had said that in the future Israel would mingle with the Gentiles, the two peoples being brought together into one fold and under the hand of one chief Shepherd, the good (Shepherd) by nature, that is, Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:114
verses.text: In blessing him Moses said, "Zabulun shall rejoice".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:115
verses.text: And Moses prophesies, that in the allocation of the land he should have abundance ministered of the good things both of land and sea, under the hand of One.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:116
verses.text: "By a haven of ships;" that is, as in an anchorage that proves safe, referring to Christ, the anchor of hope.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:117
verses.text: For by His grace he shall come forth out of many a tempest, and shall be brought hereafter to land, like ships secure in harbours.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:118
verses.text: Besides, he said that "he extends as far even as Sidon," indicating, as it seems, that so complete a unity will be effected in the spirit's course between the two peoples, that those of the blood of Israel shall occupy those very cities which once were exceeding guilty in the sight of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:119
verses.text: After something from Cyril:â  Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:120
verses.text: And "that the land was fat;" that is, the flesh of our Lord: "fat," that is, "rich;" for it flows with honey and milk.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:121
verses.text: The parts of the land are marked off for an inheritance and possession to himâthat means the doctrine of the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:122
verses.text: For this is a pleasant rest, as He says Himself: "Come unto me, all ye that labour and are heavy laden," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:123
verses.text: For they who keep the commandments, and do not disclaim the ordinances of the law, enjoy rest both in them and in the doctrine of our Lord; and that is the meaning of "in the midst of the lots".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:124
verses.text: As the Lord says, "I am not come to destroy the law and the prophets, but to fulfil them".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:125
verses.text: For even our Lord, in the fact that He keeps the commandments, does not destroy the law and the prophets, but fulfils them, as He says in the Gospels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:126
verses.text: "He set his shoulder to toil, and became a husbandman".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:127
verses.text: This the apostles did.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:128
verses.text: Having received power from God, and having set themselves to labour, they became husbandmen of the Lord, cultivating the earthâthat is, the human raceâwith the preaching of our Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:129
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:130
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:131
verses.text: â Dan shall judge his people, as himself also one tribe in Israel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:132
verses.text: And let Dan become a serpent by the way, lying on the path, stinging the horse's heel; and the horseman shall fall backward, waiting for the salvation of the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:133
verses.text: Gadâa robber's troop shall rob him; and he shall spoil it at the heels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:134
verses.text: Aserâhis bread shall be fat, and he shall furnish dainties to princes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:135
verses.text: After something from Cyril, Apollinaris, and Diodorus:â  Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:136
verses.text: The Lord is represented to us as a horseman; and the "heel" points us to the "last times".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:137
verses.text: And His "falling" denotes His death; as it is written in the Gospel: "Behold, this (child) is set for the fall and rising again of many".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:138
verses.text: We take the "robber" to be the traitor.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:139
verses.text: Nor was there any other traitor to the Lord save the (Jewish) people.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:140
verses.text: "Shall rob him," i-e:, shall plot against him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:141
verses.text: At the heels:  that refers to the help of the Lord against those who lie in wait against Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:142
verses.text: And again, the words "at the heels" denote that the Lord will take vengeance swiftly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:143
verses.text: He shall be well armed in the foot (heel), and shall overtake and rob the robber's troop.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:144
verses.text: Aquila.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:145
verses.text: "Girded, he shall gird himself;" that means that as a man of arms and war he shall arm himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:146
verses.text: "And he shall be armed in the heel:" he means this rather, that Gad shall follow behind his brethren in arms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:147
verses.text: For though his lot was beyond Jordan, yet they (the men of that tribe) were enjoined to follow their brethren in arms until they too got their lots.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:148
verses.text: Or perhaps he meant this, that Gad's tribesmen were to live in the manner of robbers, and that he was to take up a confederacy of freebooters, which is just a "robber's troop," and to follow them, practising piracy, which is robbery, along with them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:149
verses.text: Whereas, on the abolition of the shadow in the law, and the introduction of the worship in spirit and truth, the world had need of greater light, at last, with this object, the inspired disciples were called, and put in possession of the lot of the teachers of the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:150
verses.text: For thus did God speak with regard to the mother of the Jewsâthat is to say, Jerusalemâby the voice of the Psalmist: "Instead of thy fathers were thy sons;" that is, to those called thy sons was given the position of fathers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:151
verses.text: And with regard to our Lord Jesus Christ in particular: "Thou wilt appoint them rulers over all the earth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:152
verses.text: Yet presently their authority will not be by any means void of trouble to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:153
verses.text: Nay rather, they were to experience unnumbered ills and they were to be in perplexity; and the course of their apostleship they were by no means to find free of peril, as he intimated indeed by way of an example, when he said, "Let (Dan) be," meaning by that, that there shall be a multitude of persecutors in Dan like a "serpent lying by the way on the path, stinging the horse's heel," i-e:, giving fierce and dangerous bites; for the bites of snakes are generally very dangerous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:154
verses.text: And they were "in the heel" in particular, for "he shall bruise thy head, and thou shalt bruise his heel".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:155
verses.text: And some did persecute the holy apostles in this way even to the death of the flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:156
verses.text: And thus we may say that their position was something like that when a horse stumbles and flings out his heels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:157
verses.text: For in such a case the horseman will be thrown, and, falling to the ground, I suppose, he waits thus for some one alive.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:158
verses.text: And thus, too, the inspired apostles survive and wait for the time of their redemption, when they shall be called into a kingdom which cannot be moved, when Christ addresses them with the word, "Come, ye blessed of my Father," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:159
verses.text: And again, if any one will take the words as meaning, not that there will be some lying in wait against Dan like serpents, but that this Dan himself lies in wait against others, we may say that those meant thereby are the scribes and Pharisees, hypocrites who, while in possession of the power of judgment and instruction among the people, fastened like snakes upon Christ, and strove impiously to compass His fall, vexing Him with their stings as He held on in His lofty and gentle course.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:160
verses.text: But if that horseman did indeed fall, He fell at least of His own will, voluntarily enduring the death of the flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:161
verses.text: And, moreover, it was destined that He should come to life again, having the Father as His helper and conductor.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:162
verses.text: For the Son, being the power of God the Father, endued the temple of His own body again with life.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:163
verses.text: Thus is He said to have been saved by the Father, as He stood in peril as a man, though by nature He is God, and Himself maintains the whole creation, visible and invisible, in a state of wellbeing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:164
verses.text: In this sense, also, the inspired Paul says of Him: "Though He was crucified in weakness, yet He liveth by the power of God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:165
verses.text: Aser obtained the parts about Ptolemais and Sidon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:166
verses.text: Wherefore he says, "His bread shall be fat, and he shall furnish dainties to princes".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:167
verses.text: This we take to be a figure of our calling; for "fat" means "rich".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:168
verses.text: And whose bread is rich, if not ours?  For the Lord is our bread, as He says Himself: "I am the bread of life".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:169
verses.text: And who else will furnish dainties to princes but our Lord Jesus Christ?ânot only to the believing among the Gentiles, but also to those of the circumcision, who are first in the faith, to wit, to the fathers, and the patriarchs, and the prophets, and to all who believe in His name and passion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:170
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:171
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:172
verses.text: â  Nephthalim is a slender thing, showing beauty in the shoot.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:173
verses.text: Joseph is a goodly son; my goodly, envied son; my youngest son.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:174
verses.text: Turn back to me.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:175
verses.text: Against him the archers took counsel together, and reviled him, and pressed him sore.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:176
verses.text: And their bows were broken with might, and the sinews of the arms of their hands were relaxed by the hand of the Mighty One of Jacob.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:177
verses.text: Thence is he who strengthened Israel from the God of thy father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:178
verses.text: And my God helped thee, and blessed thee with the blessing of heaven above, and with the blessing of the earth which possesseth all things, with the blessing of the breasts and womb, with the blessing of thy father and thy mother.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:179
verses.text: It prevailed above the blessings of abiding mountains, and above the blessings of everlasting hills; which (blessings) shall be upon the head of Joseph, and upon the temples of his brothers, whose chief he was.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:180
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:181
verses.text: Who is the son goodly and envied, even to this day, but our Lord Jesus Christ?  An object of envy is He indeed to those who choose to hate Him, yet He is not by any means to be overcome.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:182
verses.text: For though He endured the cross, yet as God He returned to life, having trampled upon death, as His God and Father addresses Him, and says, "Sit Thou at my right hand".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:183
verses.text: And that even those are brought to nought who strive with the utmost possible madness against Him, he has taught us, when he says, "Against Him the archers took counsel together, and reviled Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:184
verses.text: For the "archers"âthat is, the leaders of the peopleâdid convene their assemblies, and take bitter counsel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:185
verses.text: "But their bows were broken, and the sinews of their arms were relaxed, by the hand of the Mighty One of Jacob," that is to say, by God the Father, who is the Lord of power, who also made His Son blessed in heaven and on earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:186
verses.text: And he (Naphtali) is adopted as a figure of things pertaining to us, as the Gospel shows: "The land of Zabulun, and the land of Nephthalim, by the way of the sea, beyond Jordan," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:187
verses.text: ; and, "To them that sat in darkness light has arisen".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:188
verses.text: And what other light was this but the calling of the Gentiles, which is the trunk, i-e:, the tree of the Lord, in whom engrafted it bears fruit? And the word, "giving increase of beauty in the case of the shoot," expresses the excellency of our calling.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:189
verses.text: And if the words, "giving increase of beauty in the case of the shoot," are understood, as perhaps they may, with reference to us, the clause is still quite intelligible.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:190
verses.text: For, by progressing in virtue, and attaining to better things, "reaching forth to those things which are before," according to the word of the blessed Paul, we rise ever to the higher beauty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:191
verses.text: I mean, however, of course, spiritual beauty, so that to us too it may be said hereafter, "The King greatly desired thy beauty".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:192
verses.text: After something from Apollinaris:â  Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:193
verses.text: The word of prophecy passes again to Immanuel Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:194
verses.text: For, in my opinion, what is intended by it is just what has been already stated in the words, "giving increase of beauty in the case of the shoot".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:195
verses.text: For he means that He increased and grew up into that which He had been from the beginning, and indicates the return to the glory which He had by nature.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:196
verses.text: This, if we apprehend it correctly, is (we should say) just "restored" to Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:197
verses.text: For as the only begotten Word of God, being God of God, emptied Himself, according to the Scriptures, humbling Himself of His own will to that which He was not before, and took unto Himself this vile flesh, and appeared in the "form of a servant," and "became obedient to God the Father, even unto death," so hereafter He is said to be "highly exalted;" and as if well-nigh He had it not by reason of His humanity, and as if it were in the way of grace, He "receives the name which is above every name," according to the word of the blessed Paul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:198
verses.text: But the matter, in truth, was not a "giving," as for the first time, of what He had not by nature; far otherwise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:199
verses.text: But rather we must understand a return and restoration to that which existed in Him at the beginning, essentially and inseparably.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:200
verses.text: And it is for this reason that, when He had assumed, by divine arrangement, the lowly estate of humanity, He said, "Father, glorify me with the glory which I had," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:201
verses.text: For He who was co-existent with His Father before all time.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:202
verses.text: and before the foundation of the world, always had the glory proper to Godhead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:203
verses.text: "He" too may very well be understood as the "youngest (son)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:204
verses.text: For He appeared in the last times, after the glorious and honourable company of the holy prophets, and simply once, after all those who, previous to the time of His sojourn, were reckoned in the number of sons by reason of excellence.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:205
verses.text: That Immanuel, however, was an" object of envy," is a somewhat doubtful phrase.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:206
verses.text: Yet He is an "object of envy" or "emulation" to the saints, who aspire to follow His footsteps, and conform themselves to His divine beauty, and make Him the pattern of their conduct, and win thereby their highest glory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:207
verses.text: And again, He is an "object of envy" in another sense,âan "object of ill-will," namely, to those who are declared not to love Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:208
verses.text: I refer to the leading parties among the Jews,âthe scribes, in sooth, and the Pharisees,âwho travailed with bitter envy against Him, and made the glory of which He could not be spoiled the ground of their slander, and assailed Him in many ways.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:209
verses.text: For Christ indeed raised the dead to life again, when they already stank and were corrupt; and He displayed other signs of divinity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:210
verses.text: And these should have filled them with wonder, and have made them ready to believe, and to doubt no longer.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:211
verses.text: Yet this was not the case with them; but they were consumed with ill-will, and nursed its bitter pangs in their mind.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:212
verses.text: After something from Cyril:â  Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:213
verses.text: Who else is this than as is shown us by the apostle, "the second man, the Lord from heaven?" And in the Gospel, He said that he who did the will of the Father was "the last".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:214
verses.text: And by the words, "Turn back to me," is meant His ascension to His Father in heaven after His passion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:215
verses.text: And in the phrase, "Against Him they took counsel together, and reviled Him," who are intended but just the people in their opposition to our Lord? And as to the words, "they pressed Him sore," who pressed Him, and to this day still press Him sore? Thoseâthese "archers," namelyâwho think to contend against the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:216
verses.text: But though they prevailed to put Him to death, yet "their bows were broken with might".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:217
verses.text: This plainly means, that "after the resurrection" their bows were broken with might.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:218
verses.text: And those intended are the leaders of the people, who set themselves in array against Him, and, as it were, sharpened the points of their weapons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:219
verses.text: But they failed to transfix Him, though they did what was unlawful, and dared to assail Him even in the manner of wild beasts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:220
verses.text: "Thou didst prevail above the blessings of abiding mountains".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:221
verses.text: By "eternal and abiding mountains and everlasting hills," he means the saints, because they are lifted above the earth, and make no account of the things that perish, but seek the things that are above, and aspire earnestly to rise to the highest virtues.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:222
verses.text: After the glory of Christ, therefore, are those of the Fathers who were most illustrious, and reached the greatest elevation in virtue.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:223
verses.text: These, however, were but servants; but the Lord, the Son, supplied them with the means by which they became illustrious.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:224
verses.text: Wherefore also they acknowledge (the truth of this word), "Out of His fulness have all we received".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:225
verses.text: "And my God helped thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:226
verses.text: This indicates clearly that the aid and support of the Son came from no one else but our God and Father in heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:227
verses.text: And by the word "my God," is meant that the Spirit speaks by Jacob.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:228
verses.text: Euseb.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:229
verses.text: "The sinews of the arms".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:230
verses.text: He could not say, of "the hands" or "shoulders;" but since the broad central parts of the bow are termed "arms," he says appropriately "arms".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:231
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:232
verses.text: "Blessings of the breasts and womb".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:233
verses.text: By this is meant that the true blessing from heaven is the Spirit descending through the Word upon flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:234
verses.text: And by "breasts and womb" he means the blessings of the Virgin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:235
verses.text: And by that of "thy father and thy mother," he means also the blessing of the Father which we have received in the Church through our Lord Jesus Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:236
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:237
verses.text: xlix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:238
verses.text: "Benjamin is a ravening wolf; in the morning he shall devour still, and till evening he apportions food".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:239
verses.text: Hipp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:240
verses.text: This thoroughly suits Paul, who was of the tribe of Benjamin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:241
verses.text: For when he was young, he was a ravening wolf; but when he believed, he "apportioned" food.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:242
verses.text: This also is shown us by the grace of our Lord Jesus Christ, that the tribe of Benjamin is among the first persecutors, which is the sense of "in the morning".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 2:243
verses.text: For Saul, who was of the tribe of Benjamin, persecuted David, who was appointed to be a type of the Lord.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3:1
verses.text: From the Commentary of the Holy Hippolytus of Rome Upon Genesis.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3:2
verses.text: Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3:3
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3:4
verses.text: "And God formed man of the dust of the ground".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3:5
verses.text: And what does this import? Are we to say, according to the opinion of some, that there were three men made, one spiritual, one animal, and one earthy? Not such is the case, but the whole narrative is of one man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3:6
verses.text: For the word, "Let us make," is about the man that was to be; and then comes the word, "God made man of the dust of the ground," so that the narrative is of one and the same man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 3:7
verses.text: For then He says, "Let him be made," and now He "makes him," and the narrative tells "how" He makes him.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:1
verses.text: Quoted in Jerome, Epist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:2
verses.text: , ad Damasum, Num.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:3
verses.text: xviii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:4
verses.text: (from Galland).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:5
verses.text: Isaac conveys a figure of God the Father; Rebecca of the Holy Spirit; Esau of the first people and the devil; Jacob of the Church, or of Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:6
verses.text: That Isaac was old, points to the end of the world; that his eyes were dim, denotes that faith had perished from the world, and that the light of religion was neglected before him; that the elder son is called, expresses the Jews' possession of the law; that the father loves his meat and venison, denotes the saving of men from error, whom every righteous man seeks to gain (lit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:7
verses.text: hunt for) by doctrine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:8
verses.text: The word of God here is the promise anew of the blessing and the hope of a kingdom to come, in which the saints shall reign with Christ, and keep the true Sabbath.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:9
verses.text: Rebecca is full of the Holy Spirit, as understanding the word which she heard before she gave birth, "For the elder shall serve the younger".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:10
verses.text: As a figure of the Holy Spirit, moreover, she cares for Jacob in preference.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:11
verses.text: She says to her younger son, "Go to the flock and fetch me two kids," prefiguring the Saviour's advent in the flesh to work a mighty deliverance for them who were held liable to the punishment of sin; for indeed in all the Scriptures kids are taken for emblems of sinners.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:12
verses.text: His being charged to bring "two," denotes the reception of two peoples: by the "tender and good," are meant teachable and innocent souls.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:13
verses.text: The robe or raiment of Esau denotes the faith and Scriptures of the Hebrews, with which the people of the Gentiles were endowed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:14
verses.text: The skins which were put upon his arms are the sins of both peoples, which Christ, when His hands were stretched forth on the cross, fastened to it along with Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:15
verses.text: In that Isaac asks of Jacob why he came so soon, we take him as admiring the quick faith of them that believe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:16
verses.text: That savoury meats are offered, denotes an offering pleasing to God, the salvation of sinners.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:17
verses.text: After the eating follows the blessing, and he delights in his smell.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:18
verses.text: He announces with clear voice the perfection of the resurrection and the kingdom, and also how his brethren who believe in Israel adore him and serve him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:19
verses.text: Because iniquity is opposed to righteousness, Esau is excited to strife, and meditates death deceitfully, saying in his heart, "Let the days of the mourning for my father come on, and I will slay my brother Jacob".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:20
verses.text: The devil, who previously exhibited the fratricidal Jews by anticipation in Cain, makes the most manifest disclosure of them now in Esau, showing also the time of the murder: "Let the days," says he, "of the mourning for my father come on, that I may slay my brother".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:21
verses.text: Wherefore Rebeccaâthat is, patienceâtold her husband of the brother's plot: who, summoning Jacob, bade him go to Mesopotamia and thence take a wife of the family of Laban the Syrian, his mother's brother.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 4:22
verses.text: As therefore Jacob, to escape his brother's evil designs, proceeds to Mesopotamia, so Christ, too, constrained by the unbelief of the Jews, goes into Galilee, to take from thence to Himself a bride from the Gentiles, His Church.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 5

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 5:1
verses.text: On Numbers.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 5:2
verses.text: By the Holy Bishop and Martyr Hippolytus, from Balaam's Blessings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 5:3
verses.text: Now, in order that He might be shown to have together in Himself at once the nature of God and that of man,âas the apostle, too, says: "Mediator between God and men, the man Christ Jesus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 5:4
verses.text: Now a mediator is not of one man, but two,"âit was therefore necessary that Christ, in becoming the Mediator between God and men, should receive from both an earnest of some kind, that He might appear as the Mediator between two distinct persons.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:1
verses.text: On Kings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:2
verses.text: The question is raised, whether Samuel rose by the hand of the sorceress or not.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:3
verses.text: And if, indeed, we were to allow that he did rise, we should be propounding what is false.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:4
verses.text: For how could a demon call back the soul, I say not of a righteous man merely, but of any one whatever, when it had gone, and was tarrying one knew not where? But he says, how then was the woman dismayed, and how did she see in an extraordinary way men ascending? For if her vision had not been of an extraordinary kind, she would not have said, "I see gods ascending out of the earth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:5
verses.text: She invoked one, and how did there ascend many? What then? Shall we say that the souls of all who appeared ascended, and those, too, not invoked by the woman; or that what was seen was merely phantasms of them? Even this, however, will not suffice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:6
verses.text: How, he urges further, did Saul recognise (what appeared), and do obeisance? Well, Saul did not actually see, but only, on being told by the woman that the figure of one of those who ascended was the figure he desired, and taking it to be Samuel, he consulted it as such, and did it obeisance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:7
verses.text: And it could be no difficult matter for the demon to conjure up the form of Samuel, as it was known to him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:8
verses.text: How then, says he, did he foretell the calamities that were to befall Saul and Jonathan at the same time? He did foretell indeed the end of the war, and how Saul would be overcome, drawing that as an inference from the wrath of God against him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 6:9
verses.text: Just as a physician, who has no exact knowledge of the science, might yet, seeing a patient past cure, tell of his death, though he made an error as to the hour, so, too, the demon, knowing the wrath of God by Saul's deeds, and by this very attempt to consult the sorceress, foretells his defeat and his death at the same time, though in error as to the day of his death.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 7

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 7:1
verses.text: On the Psalms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 7:2
verses.text: The Argument Prefixed by Hippolytus, Bishop of Rome, to His Exposition of the Psalms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 7:3
verses.text: The book of Psalms contains new doctrine after the law of Moses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 7:4
verses.text: And after the writing of Moses, it is the second book of doctrine.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 7:5
verses.text: Now, after the death of Moses and Joshua, and after the judges, arose David, who was deemed worthy of bearing the name of father of the Saviour himself; and he first gave to the Hebrews a new style of psalmody, by which he abrogates the ordinances established by Moses with respect to sacrifices, and introduces the new hymn and a new style of jubilant praise in the worship of God; and throughout his whole ministry he teaches very many other things that went beyond the law of Moses.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 8

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 8:1
verses.text: On Psalm II.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 8:2
verses.text: From the Exposition of the Second Psalm, by the Holy Bishop Hippolytus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 8:3
verses.text: When he came into the world, He was manifested as God and man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 8:4
verses.text: And it is easy to perceive the man in Him, when He hungers and shows exhaustion, and is weary and athirst, and withdraws in fear, and is in prayer and in grief, and sleeps on a boat's pillow, and entreats the removal of the cup of suffering, and sweats in an agony, and is strengthened by an angel, and betrayed by a Judas, and mocked by Caiaphas, and set at nought by Herod, and scourged by Pilate, and derided by the soldiers, and nailed to the tree by the Jews, and with a cry commits His spirit to His Father, and drops His head and gives up the ghost, and has His side pierced with a spear, and is wrapped in linen and laid in a tomb, and is raised by the Father on the third day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 8:5
verses.text: And the divine in Him, on the other hand, is equally manifest, when He is worshipped by angels, and seen by shepherds, and waited for by Simeon, and testified of by Anna, and inquired after by wise men, and pointed out by a star, and at a marriage makes wine of water, and chides the sea when tossed by the violence of winds, and walks upon the deep, and makes one see who was blind from birth, and raises Lazarus when dead for four days, and works many wonders, and forgives sins, and grants power to His disciples.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9:1
verses.text: On Psalm XXII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9:2
verses.text: Or XXIII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9:3
verses.text: From the Commentary by the Holy Bishop and Martyr Hippolytus, on "The Lord is My Shepherd".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9:4
verses.text: And, moreover, the ark made of imperishable wood was the Saviour Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9:5
verses.text: For by this was signified the imperishable and incorruptible tabernacle of (the Lord) Himself, which gendered no corruption of sin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9:6
verses.text: For the sinner, indeed, makes this confession: "My wounds stank, and were corrupt, because of my foolishness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 9:7
verses.text: But the Lord was without sin, made of imperishable wood, as regards His humanity; that is, of the virgin and the Holy Ghost inwardly, and outwardly of the word of God, like an ark overlaid with purest gold.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:1
verses.text: On Psalm XXIII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:2
verses.text: Or XXIV.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:3
verses.text: From the Commentary by the Same, on Ps.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:4
verses.text: xxiii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:5
verses.text: He comes to the heavenly gates: angels accompany Him: and the gates of heaven were closed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:6
verses.text: For He has not yet ascended into heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:7
verses.text: Now first does He appear to the powers of heaven as flesh ascending.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 10:8
verses.text: Therefore to these powers it is said by the angels, who are the couriers of the Saviour and Lord: "Lift up your gates, ye princes; and be lifted up, ye everlasting doors: and the King of glory shall come in.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 11

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 11:1
verses.text: On Psalm CIX.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 11:2
verses.text: Or CX.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 11:3
verses.text: From the Commentary by the Same on the Great Song.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 11:4
verses.text: He who delivered from the lowest hell the man first made of earth, when lost and bound by the chains of death; He who came down from above, and exalted earth-born man on high; He who is become the preacher of the Gospel to the dead, the redeemer of souls, and the resurrection of the buried;âHe became the helper of man in his defeat, and appeared in his likeness, the first-born Word, and took upon Himself the first Adam in the Virgin; and though spiritual Himself, He made acquaintance with the earthy in the womb; though Himself the ever-living One, He made acquaintance with the dead in transgressions; Himself the heavenly One, He bore the terrestrial on high; Himself of lofty extraction, He chose, by His own subjection, to set the slave free; and making man, who turns to dust, and forms food for the serpent, unconquerable as adamant, and that, too, when hung upon the tree, He declared him lord over his victor, and is thus Himself proved conqueror by the tree.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 11:5
verses.text: Those, indeed, who do not acknowledge the incarnate Son of God now, shall have to acknowledge Him as Judge, when He who is now despised in His inglorious body, comes in His glory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 11:6
verses.text: And when the apostles came to the sepulchre on the third day, they did not find the body of Jesus; just as the children of Israel went up the mount to seek the tomb of Moses, and did not find it.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:1
verses.text: On Psalm LXXVII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:2
verses.text: Or LXXVIII.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:3
verses.text: He sent the dog-fly among them, and consumed them; and the frog, and destroyed them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:4
verses.text: He gave also their fruits to the mildew, and their labours to the locust.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:5
verses.text: He destroyed their vine with hail, and their sycamines with frost.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:6
verses.text: Now, just as, in consequence of an irregular mode of living, a deadly bilious humour may be formed in the inwards, which the physician by his art may bring on to be a sick-vomiting, without being himself chargeable with producing the sick humour in the man's body; for excess in diet was what produced it, while the physician's science only made it show itself; so, although it may be said that the painful retribution that falls upon those who are by choice wicked comes from God, it would be only in accordance with right reason, to think that ills of that kind find both their beginnings and their causes in ourselves.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:7
verses.text: For to one who lives without sin there is no darkness, no worm, no hell (Gehenna), no fire, nor any other of these words or things of terror; just as the plagues of Egypt were not for the Hebrews,âthose fine lice annoying with invisible bites, the dog-fly fastening on the body with its painful sting, the hurricanes from heaven falling upon them with hailstones, the husbandman's labours devoured by the locusts, the darkened sky, and the rest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:8
verses.text: It is God's counsel, indeed, to tend the true vine, and to destroy the Egyptian, while sparing those who are to "eat the grape of gall, and drink the deadly venom of asps".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:9
verses.text: And the sycamine of Egypt is utterly destroyed; not, however, that one which Zaccheus climbed that he might be able to see my Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:10
verses.text: And the fruits of Egypt are wasted, that is, the works of the flesh, but not the fruit of the Spirit, love, joy, and peace.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:11
verses.text: He gave up their cattle also to the hail, and their substance to the fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:12
verses.text: Symmachus renders it: "Who gave up their cattle to the plague, and their possessions to birds".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:13
verses.text: For, having met an overwhelming overthrow, they became a prey for carnivorous birds.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:14
verses.text: But, according to the Seventy, the sense is not that the hail destroyed their cattle, and the fire the rest of their substance, but that hail, falling in an extraordinary manner along with fire, destroyed utterly their vines and sycamines first of all, which were entirely unable to stand out against the first attack; then the cattle which grazed on the plains; and then every herb and tree, which the fire accompanying the hail consumed; and the affair was altogether portentous, as fire ran with the water, and was commingled with it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:15
verses.text: "For fire ran in the hail," he says; and it was thus hail, and fire burning in the hail.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:16
verses.text: David also calls the cattle and the fruit of the trees "substance," or "riches".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:17
verses.text: And it should be observed that, though the hail is recorded to have destroyed every herb and every tree, yet there were left some which the locust, as it came upon them after the fiery hail, consumed; of which it is said, that it eats up every herb, and all the fruit of the trees which the hail left behind it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:18
verses.text: Now, in a spiritual sense, there are some sheep belonging to Christ, and others belonging to the Egyptians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:19
verses.text: Those, however, which once belonged to others may become His, as the sheep of Laban became Jacob's; and contrariwise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:20
verses.text: Whichever of the sheep, moreover, Jacob rejected, he made over to Esau.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:21
verses.text: Beware, then, lest, being found in the flock of Jesus, you be set apart when gifts are sent to Esau, and be given over to Esau as reprobate and unworthy of the spiritual Jacob.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:22
verses.text: The single-minded are the sheep of Christ, and these God saves according to the word: "O Lord, Thou preservest man and beast".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:23
verses.text: They who in their folly attach themselves to godless doctrine, are the sheep of the Egyptians, and these, too, are destroyed by the hail.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:24
verses.text: And whatsoever the Egyptians possess is given over to the fire, but Abraham's substance is given to Isaac.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:25
verses.text: He discharged upon them the wrath of His anger;âanger, and wrath, and tribulation, a visitation by evil angels.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:26
verses.text: Under anger, wrath, and tribulation, he intended bitter punishments; for God is without passion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:27
verses.text: And by anger you will understand the lesser penalties, and by wrath the greater, and by tribulation the greatest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:28
verses.text: The angels also are called evil, not because they are so in their nature, or by their own will, but because they have this office, and are appointed to produce pains and sufferings,âbeing so called, therefore, with reference to the disposition of those who endure such things; just as the day of judgment is called the evil day, as being laden with miseries and pains for sinners.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 12:29
verses.text: To the same effect is the word of Isaiah, "I, the Lord, make peace, and create evil;" meaning by that, I maintain peace, and permit war.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:1
verses.text: On Proverbs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:2
verses.text: From the Commentary of St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:3
verses.text: Hippolytus on Proverbs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:4
verses.text: Proverbs, therefore, are words of exhortation serviceable for the whole path of life; for to those who seek their way to God, these serve as guides and signs to revive them when wearied with the length of the road.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:5
verses.text: These, moreover, are the proverbs of "Solomon," that is to say, the "peacemaker," who, in truth, is Christ the Saviour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:6
verses.text: And since we understand the words of the Lord without offence, as being the words of the Lord, that no one may mislead us by likeness of name, he tells us who wrote these things, and of what people he was king, in order that the credit of the speaker may make the discourse acceptable and the hearers attentive; for they are the words of that Solomon to whom the Lord said:  "I will give thee a wise and an understanding heart; so that there has been none like thee upon the earth, and after thee there shall not arise any like unto thee," and as follows in what is written of him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:7
verses.text: Now he was the wise son of a wise father; wherefore there is added the name of David, by whom Solomon was begotten.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:8
verses.text: From a child he was instructed in the sacred Scriptures, and obtained his dominion not by lot, nor by force, but by the judgment of the Spirit and the decree of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:9
verses.text: "To know wisdom and instruction".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:10
verses.text: He who knows the wisdom of God, receives from Him also instruction, and learns by it the mysteries of the Word; and they who know the true heavenly wisdom will easily understand the words of these mysteries.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:11
verses.text: Wherefore he says: "To understand the difficulties of words;" for things spoken in strange language by the Holy Spirit become intelligible to those who have their hearts right with God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:12
verses.text: These things he understands of the people of the Jews, and their guilt in the blood of Christ; for they thought that He had His conversation (citizenship) on earth only.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:13
verses.text: They will not simply obtain, but inherit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:14
verses.text: The wicked, again, even though they are exalted, are exalted only so as to have greater dishonour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:15
verses.text: For as one does not honour an ugly and misshapen fellow, if he exalts him, but only dishonours him the more, by making his shame manifest to a larger number; so also God exalts the wicked, in order that He may make their disgrace patent.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:16
verses.text: For Pharaoh was exalted, but only to have the world as his accuser.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:17
verses.text: It must be noted, that he names the law a good gift, on account of the man who takes gifts into his bosom unrighteously.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:18
verses.text: And he forsakes the law who transgresses it; the law, namely, of which he speaks, or which he has kept.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:19
verses.text: And what is meant by "exalt (fortify) her?" Surround her with holy thoughts; for you have need of large defence, since there are many things to imperil such a possession.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:20
verses.text: But if it is in our power to fortify her, and if there are virtues in our power which exalt the knowledge of God, these will be her bulwarks,âas, for example, practice, study, and the whole chain of other virtues; and the man who observes these, honours wisdom; and the reward is, to be exalted to be with her, and to be embraced by her in the chamber of heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:21
verses.text: The heterodox are the "wicked," and the transgressors of the law are "evil men," whose "ways"âthat is to say, their deedsâhe bids us not enter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:22
verses.text: He "looks right on" who has thoughts free of passion; and he has true judgments, who is not in a state of excitement about external appearances.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:23
verses.text: When he says, "Let thine eyes look right on," he means the vision of the soul; and when he gives the exhortation, "Eat honey, my son, that it may be sweet to thy palate," he uses "honey" figuratively, meaning divine doctrine, which restores the spiritual knowledge of the soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:24
verses.text: But wisdom embraces the soul also; for, says he, "love her, that she may embrace thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:25
verses.text: And the soul, by her embrace being made one with wisdom, is filled with holiness and purity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:26
verses.text: Yea more, the fragrant ointments of Christ are laid hold of by the soul's sense of smell.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:27
verses.text: Virtue occupies the middle position; whence also he says, that manly courage is the mean between boldness and cowardice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:28
verses.text: And now he mentions the "right," not meaning thereby things which are right by nature, such as the virtues, but things which seem to thee to be right on account of their pleasures.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:29
verses.text: Now pleasures are not simply sensual enjoyments, but also riches and luxury.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:30
verses.text: And the "left" indicates envy, robberies, and the like.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:31
verses.text: For "Boreas," says he, "is a bitter wind, and yet is called by name right".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:32
verses.text: For, symbolically, under Boreas he designates the wicked devil by whom every flame of evil is kindled in the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:33
verses.text: And this has the name "right," because an angel is called by a right (propitious) name.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:34
verses.text: Do thou, says he, turn aside from evil, and God will take care of thine end; for He will go before thee, scattering thine enemies, that thou mayest go in peace.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:35
verses.text: He shows also, by the mention of the creature (the hind), the purity of that pleasure; and by the roe he intimates the quick responsive affection of the wife.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:36
verses.text: And whereas he knows many things to excite, he secures them against these, and puts upon them the indissoluble bond of affection, setting constancy before them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:37
verses.text: And as for the rest, wisdom, figuratively speaking, like a stag, can repel and crush the snaky doctrines of the heterodox.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:38
verses.text: Let her therefore, says he, be with thee, like a roe, to keep all virtue fresh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:39
