verses.text: And whereas a wife and wisdom are not in this respect the same, let her rather lead thee; for thus thou shalt conceive good thoughts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:40
verses.text: That thou mayest not say, What harm is there in the eyes, when there is no necessity that he should be perverted who looks? he shows thee that desire is a fire, and the flesh is like a garment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:41
verses.text: The latter is an easy prey, and the former is a tyrant.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:42
verses.text: And when anything harmful is not only taken within, but also held fast, it will not go forth again until it has made an exit for itself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:43
verses.text: For he who looks upon a woman, even though he escape the temptation, does not come away pure of all lust.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:44
verses.text: And why should one have trouble, if he can be chaste and free of trouble? See what Job says: "I made a covenant with mine eyes, that I should not think of another's wife".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:45
verses.text: Thus well does he know the power of abuse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:46
verses.text: And Paul for this reason kept "under his body, and brought it into subjection".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:47
verses.text: And, figuratively speaking, he keeps a fire in his breast who permits an impure thought to dwell in his heart.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:48
verses.text: And he walks upon coals who, by sinning in act, destroys his own soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:49
verses.text: The "cemphus" is a kind of wild sea-bird, which has so immoderate an impulse to sexual enjoyment, that its eyes seem to fill with blood in coition; and it often blindly falls into snares, or into the hands of men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:50
verses.text: To this, therefore, he compares the man who gives himself up to the harlot on account of his immoderate lust; or else on account of the insensate folly of the creature, for he, too, pursues his object like one senseless.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:51
verses.text: And they say that this bird is so much pleased with foam, that if one should hold foam in his hand as he sails, it will sit upon his hand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:52
verses.text: And it also brings forth with pain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:53
verses.text: You have seen her mischief.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:54
verses.text: Wait not to admit the rising of lust; for her death is everlasting.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:55
verses.text: And for the rest, by her words, her arguments in sooth, she wounds, and by her sins she kills those who yield to her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:56
verses.text: For many are the forms of wickedness that lead the foolish down to hell.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:57
verses.text: And the chambers of death mean either its depths or its treasure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:58
verses.text: How, then, is escape possible?  He intends the new Jerusalem, or the sanctified flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:59
verses.text: By the seven pillars he means the sevenfold unity of the Holy Spirit resting upon it; as Isaiah testifies, saying, "She has slain" her "victims".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:60
verses.text: Observe that the wise man must be useful to many; so that he who is useful only to himself cannot be wise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:61
verses.text: For great is the condemnation of wisdom if she reserves her power simply for the one possessing her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:62
verses.text: But as poison is not injurious to another body, but only to that one which takes it, so also the man who turns out wicked will injure himself, and not another.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:63
verses.text: For no man of real virtue is injured by a wicked man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:64
verses.text: The fruit of righteousness and the tree of life is Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:65
verses.text: He alone, as man, fulfilled all righteousness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:66
verses.text: And with His own underived life He has brought forth the fruits of knowledge and virtue like a tree, whereof they that eat shall receive eternal life, and shall enjoy the tree of life in paradise, with Adam and all the righteous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:67
verses.text: But the souls of the unrighteous meet an untimely expulsion from the presence of God, by whom they shall be left to remain in the flame of torment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:68
verses.text: Not from men, but with the Lord, will he obtain favour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:69
verses.text: He asks of wisdom, who seeks to know what is the will of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:70
verses.text: And he will show himself prudent who is sparing of his words on that which he has come to learn.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:71
verses.text: If one inquires about wisdom, desiring to learn something about wisdom, while another asks nothing of wisdom, as not only wishing to learn nothing about wisdom himself, but even keeping back his neighbours from so doing, the former certainly is deemed to be more prudent than the latter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:72
verses.text: As to the horse-leech.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:73
verses.text: There were three daughters fondly loved by sinâfornication, murder, and idolatry.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:74
verses.text: These three did not satisfy her, for she is not to be satisfied.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:75
verses.text: In destroying man by these actions, sin never varies, but only grows continually.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:76
verses.text: For the fourth, he continues, is never content to say "enough," meaning that it is universal lust.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:77
verses.text: In naming the "fourth," he intends lust in the universal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:78
verses.text: For as the body is one, and yet has many members; so also sin, being one, contains within it many various lusts by which it lays its snares for men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:79
verses.text: Wherefore, in order to teach us this, he uses the examples of Sheol (Hades), and the love of women, and hell (Tartarus), and the earth that is not filled with water.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:80
verses.text: And water and fire, indeed, will never say, "It is enough".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:81
verses.text: And the grave (Hades) in no wise ceases to receive the souls of unrighteous men; nor does the love of sin, in the instance of the love of women, cease to be given to fornication, and it becomes the betrayer of the soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:82
verses.text: And as Tartarus, which is situated in a doleful and dark locality, is not touched by a ray of light, so is every one who is the slave of sin in all the passions of the flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:83
verses.text: Like the earth not filled with water he is never able to come to confession, and to the laver of regeneration, and like water and fire, never says, "It is enough".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:84
verses.text: For as a serpent cannot mark its track upon a rock, so the devil could not find sin in the body of Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:85
verses.text: For the Lord says, "Behold, the prince of this world cometh, and will find nothing in me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:86
verses.text: âFor as a ship, sailing in the sea, leaves no traces of her way behind her, so neither does the Church, which is situate in the world as in a sea, leave her hope upon the earth, because she has her life reserved in heaven; and as she holds her way here only for a short time, it is not possible to trace out her course.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:87
verses.text: âAs the Church does not leave her hope behind in the world, her hope in the incarnation of Christ which bears us all good, she did not leave the track of death in Hades.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:88
verses.text: âOf whom but of Him who is born of the Holy Spirit and the Virgin?âwho, in renewing the perfect man in the world, works miracles, beginning from the baptism of John, as the Evangelist also testifies: And Jesus was then beginning to be about thirty years of age.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:89
verses.text: This, then, was the youthful and blooming period of the age of Him who, in journeying among the cities and districts, healed the diseases and infirmities of men.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:90
verses.text: "The eye that mocketh at his father, and dishonours the old age of his mother".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:91
verses.text: That is to say, one that blasphemes God and despises the mother of Christ, the wisdom of God,âhis eyes may ravens from the caves tear out, i-e:, him may unclean and wicked spirits deprive of the clear eye of gladness; and may the young eagles devour him: and such shall be trodden under the feet of the saints.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:92
verses.text: "There be three things which I cannot understand, and the fourth I know not: the tracks of an eagle flying," i-e:, Christ's ascension; "and the ways of a serpent upon a rock," i-e:, that the devil did not find a trace of sin in the body of Christ; "and the ways of a ship crossing the sea," i-e:, the ways of the Church, which is in this life as in a sea, and which is directed by her hope in Christ through the cross; "and the ways of a man in youth,"âthe ways of Him, namely, who is born of the Holy Spirit and the Virgin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:93
verses.text: For behold, says the Scripture, a man whose name is the Rising.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:94
verses.text: "Such is the way of an adulterous woman, who, when she has done the deed of sin, wipeth herself, and will say that no wickedness has been done".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:95
verses.text: Such is the conduct of the Church that believes on Christ, when, after committing fornication with idols, she renounces these and the devil, and is cleansed of her sins and receives forgiveness, and then asserts that she has done no wickedness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:96
verses.text: "By three things the earth is moved," viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:97
verses.text: , by the Father, the Son, and the Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:98
verses.text: "And the fourth it cannot bear," viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:99
verses.text: , the last appearing of Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:100
verses.text: "When a servant reigneth:" Israel was a slave in Egypt, and in the land of promise became a ruler.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:101
verses.text: "And a fool when he is filled with meat:" i-e:, getting the land in possession readily, and eating its fruit, and being filled, it (the people) kicked.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:102
verses.text: "And a handmaid when she casts out her mistress:"  i-e:, the synagogue which took the life of the Lord, and crucified the flesh of Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:103
verses.text: "There be four things which are least upon the earth, and these are wiser than the wise: The ants have no strength, yet they prepare their meat in the summer".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:104
verses.text: And in like manner, the Gentiles by faith in Christ prepare for themselves eternal life through good works.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:105
verses.text: "And the conies, a feeble folk, have made their houses in the rocks".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:106
verses.text: The Gentiles, that is to say, are built upon Christ, the spiritual rock, which is become the head of the corner.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:107
verses.text: "The spider, that supports itself upon its hands, and is easily caught, dwells in the strongholds of kings".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:108
verses.text: That is, the thief with his hands extended (on the cross), rests on the cross of Christ and dwells in Paradise, the stronghold of the three KingsâFather, Son, and Holy Ghost.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:109
verses.text: "The locust has no king, and yet marches out in array as by one command".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:110
verses.text: The Gentiles had no king, for they were ruled by sin; but now, believing God, they engage in the heavenly warfare.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:111
verses.text: "There be three things which go well, and the fourth which is comely in going;" that is, the angels in heaven, the saints upon earth, and the souls of the righteous under the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:112
verses.text: And the fourth, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:113
verses.text: God, the Word Incarnate, passed in honour through the Virgin's womb; and creating our Adam anew, he passed through the gates of heaven, and became the first-fruits of the resurrection and of the ascension for all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:114
verses.text: "The whelp of the lion is stronger than the beasts:" i-e:, Christ as prophesied of by Jacob in the person of Judah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:115
verses.text: "A cock walking with high spirit among his dames:" such was Paul, when preaching boldly among the churches the word of the Christ of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:116
verses.text: "A goat heading the herd:" such is He who was offered for the sins of the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:117
verses.text: "And a king speaking among the people:"  so Christ reigns over the nations, and speaks by prophets and apostles the word of truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:118
verses.text: That is one confirmed in wickedness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:119
verses.text: The apostle, too, says, "Them that sin, rebuke before all;" that is to say, all but reprobate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:120
verses.text: Who are meant by the "conies," but we ourselves, who once were like hogs, walking in all the filthiness of the world; but now, believing in Christ, we build our houses upon the holy flesh of Christ as upon a rock?  The shaking (of the earth) signifies the change of things upon earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:121
verses.text: âSin, then, which in its own nature is a slave, has reigned in the mortal body of men: once, indeed, at the time of the flood; and again in the time of the Sodomites, who, not satisfied with what the land yielded, offered violence to strangers; and a third time in the case of hateful Egypt, which, though it obtained in Joseph a man who distributed food to all, that they might not perish of famine, yet did not take well with his prosperity, but persecuted the children of Israel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:122
verses.text: "The handmaid casting out her mistress:" i-e:, the Church of the Gentiles, which, though itself a slave and a stranger to the promises, cast out the free-born and lordly synagogue, and became the wife and bride of Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:123
verses.text: By Father, Son, and Holy Spirit, the whole earth is moved.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 13:124
verses.text: The "fourth it cannot bear:" for He came first by lawgivers, and secondly by prophets, and thirdly by the Gospel, manifesting Himself openly; and in the fourth instance He shall come as the Judge of the living and the dead, whose glory the whole creation will not be able to endure.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:1
verses.text: Another Fragment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:2
verses.text: St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:3
verses.text: Hippolytus on Prov.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:4
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:5
verses.text: , "Wisdom Hath Builded Her House".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:6
verses.text: Christ, he means, the wisdom and power of God the Father, hath builded His house, i-e:, His nature in the flesh derived from the Virgin, even as he (John) hath said beforetime, "The Word became flesh, and dwelt among us".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:7
verses.text: As likewise the wise prophet testifies:  Wisdom that was before the world, and is the source of life, the infinite "Wisdom of God, hath builded her house" by a mother who knew no man,âto wit, as He assumed the temple of the body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:8
verses.text: "And hath raised her seven pillars;" that is, the fragrant grace of the all-holy Spirit, as Isaiah says: "And the seven spirits of God shall rest upon Him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:9
verses.text: But others say that the seven pillars are the seven divine orders which sustain the creation by His holy and inspired teaching; to wit, the prophets, the apostles, the martyrs, the hierarchs, the hermits, the saints, and the righteous.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:10
verses.text: And the phrase, "She hath killed her beasts," denotes the prophets and martyrs who in every city and country are slain like sheep every day by the unbelieving, in behalf of the truth, and cry aloud, "For thy sake we are killed all the day long, we were counted as sheep for the slaughter".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:11
verses.text: And again, "She hath mingled her wine" in the bowl, by which is meant, that the Saviour, uniting his Godhead, like pure wine, with the flesh in the Virgin, was born of her at once God and man without confusion of the one in the other.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:12
verses.text: "And she hath furnished her table:" that denotes the promised knowledge of the Holy Trinity; it also refers to His honoured and undefiled body and blood, which day by day are administered and offered sacrificially at the spiritual divine table, as a memorial of that first and ever-memorable table of the spiritual divine supper.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:13
verses.text: And again, "She hath sent forth her servants:" Wisdom, that is to say, has done soâChrist, to witâsummoning them with lofty announcement.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:14
verses.text: "Whoso is simple, Let him turn to me," she says, alluding manifestly to the holy apostles, who traversed the whole world, and called the nations to the knowledge of Him in truth, with their lofty and divine preaching.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 14:15
verses.text: And again, "And to those that want understanding she said"âthat is, to those who have not yet obtained the power of the Holy Ghostâ"Come, eat of my bread, and drink of the wine which I have mingled for you;" by which is meant, that He gave His divine flesh and honoured blood to us, to eat and to drink it for the remission of sins.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:1
verses.text: On the Song of Songs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:2
verses.text: Arise, O north wind, and come, thou south; blow upon my garden, that the spices thereof may flow out (Canticles iv.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:3
Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:4
verses.text: As Joseph was delighted with these spices, he is designated the King's son by God; as the Virgin Mary was anointed with them, she conceived the Word: then new secrets, and new truth, and a new kingdom, and also great and inexplicable mysteries, are made manifest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:5
verses.text: And where is all this rich knowledge? and where are these mysteries? and where are the books? For the only ones extant are Proverbs, and Wisdom, and Ecclesiastes, and the Song of Songs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:6
verses.text: What then? Does the Scripture speak falsely?  God forbid.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:7
verses.text: But the matter of his writings was various, as is shown in the phrase "Song of Songs;" for that indicates that in this one book he digested the contents of the , songs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:8
verses.text: In the days moreover of Hezekiah, there were some of the books selected for use, and others set aside.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:9
verses.text: Whence the Scripture says, "These are the mixed Proverbs of Solomon, which the friends of Hezekiah the king copied out".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:10
verses.text: And whence did they take them, but out of the books containing the , parables and the , songs? Out of these, then, the wise friends of Hezekiah took those portions which bore upon the edification of the Church.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 15:11
verses.text: And the books of Solomon on the "Parables" and "Songs," in which he wrote of the physiology of plants, and all kinds of animals belonging to the dry land, and the air, and the sea, and of the cures of disease, Hezekiah did away with, because the people looked to these for the remedies for their diseases, and neglected to seek their healing from God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:1
verses.text: On the Prophet Isaiah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:2
verses.text: Hippolytus, (Bishop) of Rome on Hezekiah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:3
verses.text: When Hezekiah, king of Judah, was still sick and weeping, there came an angel, and said to him: "I have seen thy tears, and I have heard thy voice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:4
verses.text: Behold, I add unto thy time fifteen years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:5
verses.text: And this shall be a sign to thee from the Lord: Behold, I turn back the shadow of the degrees of the house of thy father, by which the sun has gone down, the ten degrees by which the shadow has gone down," so that day be a day of thirty-two hours.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:6
verses.text: For when the sun had run its course to the tenth hour, it returned again.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:7
verses.text: And again, when Joshua the son of Nun was fighting against the Amorites, when the sun was now inclining to its setting, and the battle was being pressed closely, Joshua, being anxious lest the heathen host should escape on the descent of night, cried out, saying, "Sun, stand thou still in Gibeon; and thou moon, in the valley of Ajalon," until I vanquish this people.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:8
verses.text: And the sun stood still, and the moon, in their places, so that day was one of twenty-four hours.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:9
verses.text: And in the time of Hezekiah the moon also turned back along with the sun, that there might be no collision between the two elemental bodies, by their bearing against each other in defiance of law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 16:10
verses.text: And Merodach the Chaldean, king of Babylon, being struck with amazement at that timeâfor he studied the science of astrology, and measured the courses of these bodies carefullyâon learning the cause, sent a letter and gifts to Hezekiah, just as also the wise men from the east did to Christ.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 17

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 17:1
verses.text: From the Discourse of St.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 17:2
verses.text: Hippolytus on the beginning of Isaiah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 17:3
verses.text: Under Egypt he meant the world, and under things made with hands its idolatry, and under the shaking its subversion and dissolution.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 17:4
verses.text: And the Lord, the Word, he represented as upon a light cloud, referring to that most pure tabernacle, in which setting up His throne, our Lord Jesus Christ came into the world to shake error.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 18

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 18:1
verses.text: We find in the commentaries, written by our predecessors, that day had thirty-two hours.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 18:2
verses.text: For when the sun had run its course, and reached the tenth hour, and the shadow had gone down by the ten degrees in the house of the temple, the sun turned back again by the ten degrees, according to the word of the Lord, and there were thus twenty hours.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 18:3
verses.text: And again, the sun accomplished its own proper course, according to the common law, and reached its setting.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 18:4
verses.text: And thus there were thirty-two hours.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:1
verses.text: On Jeremiah and Ezekiel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:2
verses.text: What were the dimensions, then, of the temple of Solomon? Its length was sixty cubits, and its breadth twenty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:3
verses.text: And it was not turned to the east, that the worshippers might not worship the rising sun, but the Lord of the sun.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:4
verses.text: And let no one marvel if, when the Scripture gives the length at forty cubits, I have said sixty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:5
verses.text: For a little after it mentions the other twenty, in describing the holy of holies, which it also names Dabir.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:6
verses.text: Thus the holy place was forty cubits, and the holy of holies other twenty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:7
verses.text: And Josephus says that the temple had two storeys, and that the whole height was one hundred and twenty cubits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:8
verses.text: For so also the book of Chronicles indicates, saying, "And Solomon began to build the house of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 19:9
verses.text: In length its first measure was sixty cubits, and its breadth twenty cubits, and its height one hundred and twenty; and he overlaid it within with pure gold".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:1
verses.text: Preface by the most holy Hippolytus, (Bishop) of Rome.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:2
verses.text: As I wish to give an accurate account of the times of the captivity of the children of Israel in Babylon, and to discuss the prophecies contained in the visions of the blessed Daniel, (as well as) his manner of life from his boyhood in Babylon, I too shall proceed to bear my testimony to that holy and righteous man, a prophet and witness of Christ, who not only declared the visions of Nebuchadnezzar the king in those times, but also trained youths of like mind with himself, and raised up faithful witnesses in the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:3
verses.text: He is born, then, in the time of the prophetic ministry of the blessed Jeremiah, and in the reign of Jehoiakim or Eliakim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:4
verses.text: Along with the other captives, he is carried off a prisoner to Babylon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:5
verses.text: Now there are born to the blessed Josiah these five sonsâJehoahaz, Eliakim, Johanan, Zedekiah, or Jeconiah, and Sadum.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:6
verses.text: And on his father's death, Jehoahaz is anointed as king by the people at the age of twenty-three years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:7
verses.text: Against him comes up Pharaoh-Necho, in the third month of his reign; and he takes him (Jehoahaz) prisoner, and carries him into Egypt, and imposes tribute on the land to the extent of one hundred talents of silver and ten talents of gold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:8
verses.text: And in his stead he sets up his brother Eliakim as king over the land, whose name also he changed to Jehoiakim, and who was then eleven years old.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:9
verses.text: Against him came up Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, and carries him off prisoner to Babylon, taking with him also some of the vessels of the house in Jerusalem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:10
verses.text: Thrown into prison as a friend of Pharaoh, and as one set up by him over the kingdom, he is released at length in the thirty-seventh year by Evil-Merodach king of Babylon; and he cut his hair short, and was counsellor to him, and ate at his table until the day that he died.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:11
verses.text: On his removal, his son Jehoiakim reigns three years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:12
verses.text: And against him came up Nebuchadnezzar, and transports him and ten thousand of the men of his people to Babylon, and sets up in his stead his father's brother, whose name he changed also to Zedekiah; and after making agreement with him by oath and treaty, he returns to Babylon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:13
verses.text: This (Zedekiah), after a reign of eleven years, revolted from him and went over to Pharaoh king of Egypt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:14
verses.text: And in the tenth year Nebuchadnezzar came against him from the land of the Chaldeans, and surrounded the city with a stockade, and environed it all round, and completely shut it up.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:15
verses.text: In this way the larger number of them perished by famine, and others perished by the sword, and some were taken prisoners, and the city was burned with fire, and the temple and the wall were destroyed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:16
verses.text: And the army of the Chaldeans seized all the treasure that was found in the house of the Lord, and all the vessels of gold and silver; and all the brass, Nebuzaradan, chief of the slaughterers, stripped off, and carried it to Babylon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:17
verses.text: And the army of the Chaldeans pursued Zedekiah himself as he fled by night along with seven hundred men, and surprised him in Jericho, and brought him to the king of Babylon at Reblatha.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:18
verses.text: And the king pronounced judgment upon him in wrath, because he had violated the oath of the Lord, and the agreement he had made with him; and he slew his sons before his face, and put out Zedekiah's eyes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:19
verses.text: And he cast him into chains of iron, and carried him to Babylon; and there he remained grinding at the mill until the day of his death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:20
verses.text: And when he died, they took his body and cast it behind the wall of Nineveh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:21
verses.text: In his case is fulfilled the prophecy of Jeremiah, saying, "(As) I live, saith the Lord, though Jeconiah son of Jehoiakim king of Judah should become the signet upon my right hand, yet will I pluck thee thence; and I will give thee into the hands of them that seek thy life, of them whose face thou fearest, even into the hands of the Chaldeans.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:22
verses.text: And I will cast thee out, and thy mother that bare thee, into a country where thou wast not born; and there ye shall die.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:23
verses.text: But to the land which they desire in their souls, I will not send thee back.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:24
verses.text: Dishonoured is Jeconias, like an unserviceable vessel, of which there is no use, since he is cast out and expelled into a land which he knew not.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:25
verses.text: O earth, hear the word of the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:26
verses.text: Write this man, a man excommunicate; for no man of his seed shall prosper (grow up), sitting upon the throne of David, ruling any more in Judah".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:27
verses.text: Thus the captivity in Babylon befell them after the exodus from Egypt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:28
verses.text: When the whole people, then, was transported, and the city made desolate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 20:29
verses.text: and the sanctuary destroyed, that the word of the Lord might be fulfilled which He spake by the mouth of the prophet Jeremiah, saying, "The sanctuary shall be desolate seventy years;" then we find that the blessed Daniel prophesied in Babylon, and appeared as the vindicator of Susanna.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:1
verses.text: The interpretation by Hippolytus, (bishop) of Rome, of the visions of Daniel and Nebuchadnezzar, taken in conjunction.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:2
verses.text: In speaking of a "lioness from the sea," he meant the rising of the kingdom of Babylon, and that this was the "golden head of the image".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:3
verses.text: And in speaking of its "eagle wings," he meant that king Nebuchadnezzar was exalted and that his glory was lifted up against God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:4
verses.text: Then he says "its wings were plucked off," i-e:, that his glory was destroyed; for he was driven out of his kingdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:5
verses.text: And the words, "A man's heart was given it, and it was made stand upon the feet of a man," mean that he came to himself again, and recognised that he was but a man, and gave the glory to God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:6
verses.text: Then after the lioness he sees a second beast, "like a bear," which signified the Persians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:7
verses.text: For after the Babylonians the Persians obtained the power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:8
verses.text: And in saying that "it had three ribs in its mouth," he pointed to the three nations, Persians, Medes, and Babylonians, which were expressed in the image by the silver after the gold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:9
verses.text: Then comes the third beast, "a leopard," which means the Greeks; for after the Persians, Alexander of Macedon had the power, when Darius was overthrown, which was also indicated by the brass in the image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:10
verses.text: And in saying that the beast "had four wings of a fowl, and four heads," he showed most clearly how the kingdom of Alexander was parted into four divisions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:11
verses.text: For in speaking of four heads, he meant the four kings that arose out of it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:12
verses.text: For Alexander, when dying, divided his kingdom into four parts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:13
verses.text: Then he says, "The fourth beast (was) dreadful and terrible: it had iron teeth, and claws of brass".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:14
verses.text: Who, then, are meant by this but the Romans, whose kingdom, the kingdom that still stands, is expressed by the iron? "for," says he, "its legs are of iron".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:15
verses.text: After this, then, what remains, beloved, but the toes of the feet of the image, in which "part shall be of iron and part of clay mixed together?" By the toes of the feet he meant, mystically, the ten kings that rise out of that kingdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:16
verses.text: As Daniel says, "I considered the beast; and, lo, (there were) ten horns behind, among which shall come up another little horn springing from them;" by which none other is meant than the antichrist that is to rise; and he shall set up the kingdom of Judah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:17
verses.text: And in saying that "three horns" were "plucked up by the roots" by this one, he indicates the three kings of Egypt, Libya, and Ethiopia, whom this one will slay in the array of war.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:18
verses.text: And when he has conquered all, he will prove himself a terrible and savage tyrant, and will cause tribulation and persecution to the saints, exalting himself against them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:19
verses.text: And after him, it remains that "the stone" shall come from heaven which "smote the image" and shivered it, and subverted all the kingdoms, and gave the kingdom to the saints of the Most High.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:20
verses.text: This "became a great mountain, and filled the whole earth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:21
verses.text: As these things, then, are destined to come to pass, and as the toes of the image turn out to be democracies, and the ten horns of the beast are distributed among ten kings, let us look at what is before us more carefully, and scan it, as it were, with open eye.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:22
verses.text: The "golden head of the image" is identical with the "lioness," by which the Babylonians were represented.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:23
verses.text: "The golden shoulders and the arms of silver" are the same with the "bear," by which the Persians and Medes are meant.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:24
verses.text: "The belly and thighs of brass" are the "leopard," by which the Greeks who ruled from Alexander onwards are intended.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:25
verses.text: The "legs of iron" are the "dreadful and terrible beast," by which the Romans who hold the empire now are meant.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:26
verses.text: The "toes of clay and iron" are the "ten horns" which are to be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:27
verses.text: The "one other little horn springing up in their midst" is the "antichrist".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:28
verses.text: The stone that "smites the image and breaks it in pieces," and that filled the whole earth, is Christ, who comes from heaven and brings judgment on the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:29
verses.text: But that we may not leave our subject at this point undemonstrated, we are obliged to discuss the matter of the times, of which a man should not speak hastily, because they are a light to him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:30
verses.text: For as the times are noted from the foundation of the world, and reckoned from Adam, they set clearly before us the matter with which our inquiry deals.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:31
verses.text: For the first appearance of our Lord in the flesh took place in Bethlehem, under Augustus, in the year ; and He suffered in the thirty-third year.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:32
verses.text: And , years must needs be accomplished, in order that the Sabbath may come, the rest, the holy day "on which God rested from all His works".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:33
verses.text: For the Sabbath is the type and emblem of the future kingdom of the saints, when they "shall reign with Christ," when He comes from heaven, as John says in his Apocalypse: for "a day with the Lord is as a thousand years".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:34
verses.text: Since, then, in six days God made all things, it follows that , years must be fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:35
verses.text: And they are not yet fulfilled, as John says: "five are fallen; one is," that is, the sixth; "the other is not yet come".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:36
verses.text: In mentioning the "other," moreover, he specifies the seventh, in which there is rest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:37
verses.text: But some one may be ready to say, How will you prove to me that the Saviour was born in the year ? Learn that easily, O man; for the things that took place of old in the wilderness, under Moses, in the case of the tabernacle, were constituted types and emblems of spiritual mysteries, in order that, when the truth came in Christ in these last days, you might be able to perceive that these things were fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:38
verses.text: For He says to him, "And thou shalt make the ark of imperishable wood, and shalt overlay it with pure gold within and without; and thou shalt make the length of it two cubits and a half, and the breadth thereof one cubit and a half, and a cubit and a half the height;" which measures, when summed up together, make five cubits and a half, so that the  years might be signified thereby.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:39
verses.text: At that time, then, the Saviour appeared and showed His own body to the world, (born) of the Virgin, who was the "ark overlaid with pure gold," with the Word within and the Holy Spirit without; so that the truth is demonstrated, and the "ark" made manifest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:40
verses.text: From the birth of Christ, then, we must reckon the  years that remain to make up the , and thus the end shall be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:41
verses.text: And that the Saviour appeared in the world, bearing the imperishable ark, His own body, at a time which was the fifth and half, John declares: "Now it was the sixth hour," he says, intimating by that, one-half of the day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:42
verses.text: But a day with the Lord is  years; and the half of that, therefore, is  years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:43
verses.text: For it was not meet that He should appear earlier, for the burden of the law still endured, nor yet when the sixth day was fulfilled (for the baptism is changed), but on the fifth and half, in order that in the remaining half time the gospel might be preached to the whole world, and that when the sixth day was completed He might end the present life.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:44
verses.text: Since, then, the Persians held the mastery for  years, and after them the Greeks, who were yet more glorious, held it for  years, of necessity the fourth beast, as being strong and mightier than all that were before it, will reign  years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:45
verses.text: When the times are fulfilled, and the ten horns spring from the beast in the last (times), then Antichrist will appear among them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:46
verses.text: When he makes war against the saints, and persecutes them, then may we expect the manifestation of the Lord from heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:47
verses.text: The prophet having thus instructed us with all exactness as to the certainty of the things that are to be, broke off from his present subject, and passed again to the kingdom of the Persians and Greeks, recounting to us another vision which took place, and was fulfilled in its proper time; in order that, by establishing our belief in this, he might be able to present us to God as readier believers in the things that are to be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:48
verses.text: Accordingly, what he had narrated in the first vision, he again recounts in detail for the edification of the faithful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:49
verses.text: For by the "ram pushing westward, and northward, and southward," he means Darius, the king of the Persians, who overcame all the nations; "for," says he, "these beasts shall not stand before him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:50
verses.text: And by the "he-goat that came from the west," he means Alexander the Macedonian, the king of the Greeks; and in that he "came against that very ram, and was moved with choler, and smote him upon the face, and shivered him, and cast him upon the ground, and stamped upon him," this expresses just what has happened.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:51
verses.text: For Alexander waged war against Darius, and overcame him, and made himself master of the whole sovereignty, after routing and destroying his camp.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:52
verses.text: Then, after the exaltation of the he-goat, his hornâthe great one, namelyâwas broken; and there arose four horns under it, toward the four winds of heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:53
verses.text: For, when Alexander had made himself master of all the land of Persia, and had reduced its people into subjection, he thereupon died, after dividing his kingdom into four principalities, as has been shown above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:54
verses.text: And from that time "one horn was exalted, and waxed great, even to the power of heaven; and by him the sacrifice," he says, "was disturbed, and righteousness cast down to the ground".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:55
verses.text: For Antiochus arose, surnamed Epiphanes, who was of the line of Alexander.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:56
verses.text: And after he had reigned in Syria, and brought under him all Egypt, he went up to Jerusalem, and entered the sanctuary, and seized all the treasures in the house of the Lord, and the golden candlestick, and the table, and the altar, and made a great slaughter in the land; even as it is written: "And the sanctuary shall be trodden under foot, unto evening and unto morning, a thousand and three hundred days".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:57
verses.text: For it happened that the sanctuary remained desolate during that period, three years and a half, that the thousand and three hundred days might be fulfilled; until Judas Maccabaeus arose after the death of his father Matthias, and withstood him, and destroyed the encampment of Antiochus, and delivered the city, and recovered the sanctuary, and restored it in strict accordance with the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:58
verses.text: Since, then, the angel Gabriel also recounted these things to the prophet, as they have been understood by us, as they have also taken place, and as they have been all clearly described in the books of the Maccabees, let us see further what he says on the other weeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:59
verses.text: For when he read the book of Jeremiah the prophet, in which it was written that the sanctuary would be desolate seventy years, he made confession with fastings and supplications, and prayed that the people might return sooner from their captivity to the city Jerusalem.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:60
verses.text: Thus, then, he speaks in his account: "In the first year of Darius the son of Ahasuerus, of the seed of the Medes, who was king over the realm of the Chaldeans, I Daniel understood in the books the number of the years, as the word of the Lord had come to Jeremiah the prophet, for the accomplishment of the desolation of Jerusalem in seventy years," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:61
verses.text: After his confession and supplication, the angel says to him, "Thou art a man greatly beloved:" for thou desirest to see things of which thou shalt be informed by me; and in their own time these things will be fulfilled; and he touched me, saying, "Seventy weeks are determined upon thy people, and upon the holy city, to seal up sins and to blot out transgressions, and to seal up vision and prophet, and to anoint the Most Holy; and thou shalt know and understand, that from the going forth of words for the answer, and for the building of Jerusalem, unto Christ the Prince, shall be seven weeks, and threescore and two weeks".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:62
verses.text: Having mentioned therefore seventy weeks, and having divided them into two parts, in order that what was spoken by him to the prophet might be better understood, he proceeds thus, "Unto Christ the Prince shall be seven weeks," which make forty-nine years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:63
verses.text: It was in the twenty-first year that Daniel saw these things in Babylon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:64
verses.text: Hence, the forty-nine years added to the twenty-one, make up the seventy years, of which the blessed Jeremiah spake: "The sanctuary shall be desolate seventy years from the captivity that befell them under Nebuchadnezzar; and after these things the people will return, and sacrifice and offering will be presented, when Christ is their Prince".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:65
verses.text: Now of what Christ does he speak, but of Jesus the son of Josedech, who returned at that time along with the people, and offered sacrifice according to the law, in the seventieth year, when the sanctuary was built? For all the kings and priests were styled Christs, because they were anointed with the holy oil, which Moses of old prepared.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:66
verses.text: These, then, bore the name of the Lord in their own persons, showing aforetime the type, and presenting the image until the perfect King and Priest appeared from heaven, who alone did the will of the Father; as also it is written in Kings:  "And I will raise me up a faithful priest, that shall do all things according to my heart".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:67
verses.text: In order, then, to show the time when He is to come whom the blessed Daniel desired to see, he says, "And after seven weeks there are other threescore and two weeks," which period embraces the space of  years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:68
verses.text: For after the return of the people from Babylon under the leadership of Jesus the son of Josedech, and Ezra the scribe, and Zerubbabel the son of Salathiel, of the tribe of David, there were  years unto the coming of Christ, in order that the Priest of priests might be manifested in the world, and that He who taketh away the sins of the world might be evidently set forth, as John speaks concerning Him: "Behold the Lamb of God, that taketh away the sin of the world!" And in like manner Gabriel says: "To blot out transgressions, and make reconciliation for sins".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:69
verses.text: But who has blotted out our transgressions? Paul the apostle teaches us, saying, "He is our peace who made both one;" and then, "Blotting out the handwriting of sins that was against us".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:70
verses.text: That transgressions, therefore, are blotted out, and that reconciliation is made for sins, is shown by this.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:71
verses.text: But who are they who have reconciliation made for their sins, but they who believe on His name, and propitiate His countenance by good works? And that after the return of the people from Babylon there was a space of  years, until the time of the birth of Christ, may be easily understood.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:72
verses.text: For, since the first covenant was given to the children of Israel after a period of  years, it follows that the second covenant also should be defined by the same space of time, in order that it might be expected by the people and easily recognised by the faithful.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:73
verses.text: And for this reason Gabriel says:  "And to anoint the Most Holy".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:74
verses.text: And the Most Holy is none else but the Son of God alone, who, when He came and manifested Himself, said to them, "The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because He has anointed me;" and so forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:75
verses.text: Whosoever, therefore, believed on the heavenly Priest, were cleansed by that same Priest, and their sins were blotted out.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:76
verses.text: And whosoever believed not on Him, despising Him as a man, had their sins sealed, as those which could not be taken away; whence the angel, foreseeing that not all should believe on Him, said, "To finish sins, and to seal up sins".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:77
verses.text: For as many as continued to disbelieve Him, even to the end, had their sins not finished, but sealed to be kept for judgment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:78
verses.text: But as many as will believe on Him as One able to remit sins, have their sins blotted out.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:79
verses.text: Wherefore he says: "And to seal up vision and prophet".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:80
verses.text: For when He came who is the fulfilling of the law and of the prophets (for the law and the prophets were till John), it was necessary that the things spoken by them should be confirmed (sealed), in order that at the coming of the Lord all things loosed should be brought to light, and that things bound of old should now be loosed by Him, as the Lord said Himself to the rulers of the people, when they were indignant at the cure on the Sabbath-day:  "Ye hypocrites, doth not each one of you loose his ox or his ass from the stall, and lead him away to watering? and ought not this woman, being a daughter of Abraham, whom Satan hath bound these eighteen years, be loosed on the Sabbath-day?" Whomsoever, therefore, Satan bound in chains, these did the Lord on His coming loose from the bonds of death, having bound our strong adversary and delivered humanity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:81
verses.text: As also Isaiah says: "Then will He say to those in chains, Go forth; and to them that are in darkness, Show yourselves".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:82
verses.text: And that the things spoken of old by the law and the prophets were all sealed, and that they were unknown to men, Isaiah declares when he says: "And they will deliver the book that is sealed to one that is learned, and will say to him, Read this; and he will say, I cannot read it, for it is sealed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:83
verses.text: It was meet and necessary that the things spoken of old by the prophets should be sealed to the unbelieving Pharisees, who thought that they understood the letter of the law, and be opened to the believing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:84
verses.text: The things, therefore, which of old were sealed, are now by the grace of God the Lord all open to the saints.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:85
verses.text: For He was Himself the perfect Seal, and the Church is the key: "He who openeth, and no man shutteth; and shutteth, and no man openeth," as John says.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:86
verses.text: And again, the same says: "And I saw, on the right hand of Him that sat on the throne, a book written within and without, sealed with seven seals; and I saw an angel proclaiming with a loud voice, Who is worthy to open the book, and to loose the seals thereof?" and so forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:87
verses.text: "And I beheld in the midst of the throne, and of the four beasts, a Lamb standing slain, having seven horns, and seven eyes, which are the seven Spirits of God sent forth into all the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:88
verses.text: And He came and took the book out of the right hand of Him that sat upon the throne.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:89
verses.text: And when He had taken the book, the four beasts and four-and-twenty elders fell down before the Lamb, having harps and golden vials full of incense, which is the prayers of the saints.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:90
verses.text: And they sing a new song, saying, Thou art worthy to take the book, and to open the seals thereof: for Thou wast slain, and hast redeemed us to God by Thy blood".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:91
verses.text: He took the book, therefore, and loosed it, in order that the things spoken concerning Him of old in secret, might now be proclaimed with boldness upon the house-tops.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:92
verses.text: For this reason, then, the angel says to Daniel, "Seal the words, for the vision is until the end of the time".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:93
verses.text: But to Christ it was not said "seal," but "loose" the things bound of old; in order that, by His grace, we might know the will of the Father, and believe upon Him whom He has sent for the salvation of men, Jesus our Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:94
verses.text: He says, therefore, "They shall return, and the street shall be built, and the wall;" which in reality took place.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:95
verses.text: For the people returned and built the city, and the temple, and the wall round about.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:96
verses.text: Then he says:  "After threescore and two weeks the times will be fulfilled, and one week will make a covenant with many; and in the midst (half) of the week sacrifice and oblation will be removed, and in the temple will be the abomination of desolations".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:97
verses.text: For when the threescore and two weeks are fulfilled, and Christ is come, and the Gospel is preached in every place, the times being then accomplished, there will remain only one week, the last, in which Elias will appear, and Enoch, and in the midst of it the abomination of desolation will be manifested, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:98
verses.text: , Antichrist, announcing desolation to the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:99
verses.text: And when he comes, the sacrifice and oblation will be removed, which now are offered to God in every place by the nations.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:100
verses.text: These things being thus recounted, the prophet again describes another vision to us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:101
verses.text: For he had no other care save to be accurately instructed in all things that are to be, and to prove himself an instructor in such.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:102
verses.text: He says then: "In the third year of Cyrus king of Persia, a word was revealed unto Daniel, whose name was Belshazzar; and the word was true, and great power and understanding were given him in the vision.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:103
verses.text: In those days I Daniel was mourning three weeks of days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:104
verses.text: I ate no pleasant bread, neither came flesh nor wine into my mouth, neither did I anoint myself at all, till three weeks of days were fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:105
verses.text: On the fourth day of the first month I humbled myself," says he, "one and twenty days," praying to the living God, and asking of Him the revelation of the mystery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:106
verses.text: And the Father in truth heard me, and sent His own Word, to show what should happen by Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:107
verses.text: And that took place, indeed, by the great river.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:108
verses.text: For it was meet that the Son should be manifested there, where also He was to remove sins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:109
verses.text: "And I lifted up mine eyes," he says, "and, behold, a man clothed in linen".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:110
verses.text: In the first vision he says, "Behold, the angel Gabriel (was) sent".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:111
verses.text: Here, however, it is not so; but he sees the Lord, not yet indeed as perfect man, but with the appearance and form of man, as he says: "And, behold, a man clothed in linen".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:112
verses.text: For in being clothed in a various-coloured coat, he indicated mystically the variety of the graces of our calling.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:113
verses.text: For the priestly coat was made up of different colours, as various nations waited for Christ's coming, in order that we might be made up (as one body) of many colours.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:114
verses.text: "And his loins were girded with the gold of Ophaz".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:115
verses.text: Now the word "Ophaz," which is a word transferred from Hebrew to Greek, denotes pure gold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:116
verses.text: With a pure girdle, therefore, he was girded round the loins.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:117
verses.text: For the Word was to bear us all, binding us like a girdle round His body, in His own love.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:118
verses.text: The complete body was His, but we are members in His body, united together, and sustained by the Word Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:119
verses.text: "And his body was like Tharses".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:120
verses.text: Now "Tharses," by interpretation, is "Ethiopians".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:121
verses.text: For that it would be difficult to recognise Him, the prophet had thus already announced beforehand, intimating that He would be manifested in the flesh in the world, but that many would find it difficult to recognise Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:122
verses.text: "And his face as lightning, and his eyes as lamps of fire;" for it was meet that the fiery and judicial power of the Word should be signified aforetime, in the exercise of which He will cause the fire (of His judgment) to light with justice upon the impious, and consume them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:123
verses.text: He added also these words:  "And his arms and his feet like polished brass;" to denote the first calling of men, and the second calling like unto it, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:124
verses.text: of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:125
verses.text: "For the last shall be as the first; for I will set thy rulers as at the beginning, and thy leaders as before.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:126
verses.text: And His voice was as the voice of a great multitude".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:127
verses.text: For all we who believe on Him in these days utter things oracular, as speaking by His mouth the things appointed by Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:128
verses.text: And after a little He says to him:  "Knowest thou wherefore I come unto thee? And now will I return to fight with the prince of Persia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:129
verses.text: But I will show thee that which is noted in the Scripture of truth: and there is none that holdeth with me in these things but Michael your prince, and I left him there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:130
verses.text: For from the day that thou didst give thy countenance to be afflicted before the Lord thy God, thy prayer was heard, and I was sent to fight with the prince of Persia:"  for a certain counsel was formed not to send the people away:  "that therefore thy prayer might be speedily granted, I withstood him, and left Michael there".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:131
verses.text: And who was he that spake, but the angel who was given to the people, as he says in the law of Moses: "I will not go with you, because the people is stiff-necked; but my angel shall go before along with you?" This (angel) withstood Moses at the inn, when he was bringing the child uncircumcised into Egypt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:132
verses.text: For it was not allowed Moses, who was the elder (or legate) and mediator of the law, and who proclaimed the covenant of the fathers, to introduce a child uncircumcised, lest he should be deemed a false prophet and deceiver by the people.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:133
verses.text: "And now," says he, "will I show the truth to thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:134
verses.text: Could the Truth have shown anything else but the truth?.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:135
verses.text: He says therefore to him: "Behold, there shall stand up three kings in Persia: and the fourth shall be far richer than they all; and when he has got possession of his riches, he shall stand up against all the realms of Grecia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:136
verses.text: And a mighty king shall stand up, and shall rule with great dominion, and do according to his will; and when his kingdom stands, it shall be broken, and shall be divided toward the four winds of heaven".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:137
verses.text: These things we have already discussed above, when we discoursed upon the four beasts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:138
verses.text: But since Scripture now again sets them forth explicitly, we must also discourse upon them a second time, that we may not leave Scripture unused and unexplained.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:139
verses.text: "There shall stand up yet three kings," he says, "in Persia; and the fourth shall be far richer than they all".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:140
verses.text: This has been fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:141
verses.text: For after Cyrus arose Darius, and then Artaxerxes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:142
verses.text: These were the three kings; (and) the Scripture is fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:143
verses.text: "And the fourth shall be far richer than they all".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:144
verses.text: Who is that but Darius, who reigned and made himself glorious,âwho was rich, and assailed all the realms of Greece? Against him rose Alexander of Macedon, who destroyed his kingdom; and after he had reduced the Persians, his own kingdom was divided toward the four winds of heaven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:145
verses.text: For Alexander at his death divided his kingdom into four principalities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:146
verses.text: "And a king shall stand up, and shall enter into the fortress of the king of Egypt".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:147
verses.text: For Antiochus became king of Syria.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:148
verses.text: He held the sovereignty in the th year of the kingdom of the Greeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:149
verses.text: And in those same times indeed he made war against Ptolemy king of Egypt, and conquered him, and won the power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:150
verses.text: On returning from Egypt he went up to Jerusalem, in the d year, and carrying off with him all the treasures of the Lord's house, he marched to Antioch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:151
verses.text: And after two years of days the king sent his raiser of taxes into the cities of Judea, to compel the Jews to forsake the laws of their fathers, and submit to the decrees of the king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:152
verses.text: And he came, and tried to compel them, saying, "Come forth, and do the commandment of the king, and ye shall live".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:153
verses.text: But they said, "We will not come forth: neither will we do the king's commandment; we will die in our innocency: and he slew of them a thousand souls".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:154
verses.text: The things, therefore, which were spoken to the blessed Daniel are fulfilled: "And my servants shall be afflicted, and shall fall by famine, and by sword, and by captivity".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:155
verses.text: Daniel, however, adds: "And they shall be holpen with a little help".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:156
verses.text: For at that time Matthias arose, and Judas Maccabaeus, and helped them, and delivered them from the hand of the Greeks.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:157
verses.text: That therefore was fulfilled which was spoken in the Scripture.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:158
verses.text: He proceeds then thus: "And the (king's) daughter of the South shall come to the king of the North to make an agreement with him; and the arms of him that bringeth her shall not stand; and she, too, shall be smitten, and shall fall, and he that bringeth her".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:159
verses.text: For this was a certain PtolemaÃ¯s, queen of Egypt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:160
verses.text: At that time indeed she went forth with her two sons, Ptolemy and Philometor, to make an agreement with Antiochus king of Syria; and when she came to Scythopolis, she was slain there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:161
verses.text: For he who brought her betrayed her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:162
verses.text: At that same time, the two brothers made war against each other, and Philometor was slain, and Ptolemy gained the power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:163
verses.text: War, then, was again made by Ptolemy against Antiochus, (and) Antiochus met him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:164
verses.text: For thus saith the Scripture: "And the king of the South shall stand up against the king of the North, and her seed shall stand up against him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:165
verses.text: And what seed but Ptolemy, who made war with Antiochus? And Antiochus having gone forth against him, and having failed to overcome him, had to flee, and returned to Antioch, and collected a larger host.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:166
verses.text: Ptolemy accordingly took his whole equipment, and carried it into Egypt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:167
verses.text: And the Scripture is fulfilled, as Daniel says: And he shall carry off into Egypt their gods, and their cast-works, and all their precious (vessels of) gold.
