verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:168
verses.text: And after these things Antiochus went forth a second time to make war against him, and overcome Ptolemy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:169
verses.text: And after these events Antiochus commenced hostilities again against the children of Israel, and despatched one Nicanor with a large army to subdue the Jews, at the time when Judas, after the death of Matthias, ruled the people; and so forth, as is written in the Maccabees.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:170
verses.text: These events having taken place, the Scripture says again: "And there shall stand up another king, and he shall prevail upon the earth; and the king of the South shall stand up, and he shall obtain his daughter to wife".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:171
verses.text: For it happened that there arose a certain Alexander, son of Philip.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:172
verses.text: He withstood Antiochus at that time, and made war upon him, and cut him off, and gained possession of the kingdom.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:173
verses.text: Then he sent to Ptolemy king of Egypt, saying, Give me thy daughter Cleopatra to wife.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:174
verses.text: And he gave her to Alexander to wife.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:175
verses.text: And thus the Scripture is fulfilled, when it says:  "And he shall obtain his daughter to wife".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:176
verses.text: And it says further: "And he shall corrupt her, and she shall not be his wife".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:177
verses.text: This also has been truly fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:178
verses.text: For after Ptolemy had given him his daughter, he returned, and saw the mighty and glorious kingdom of Alexander.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:179
verses.text: And coveting its possession, he spoke falsely to Alexander, as the Scripture says:  "And the two kings shall speak lies at (one) table".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:180
verses.text: And, in sooth, Ptolemy betook himself to Egypt, and collected a great army, and attacked the city at the time when Alexander had marched into Cilicia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:181
verses.text: Ptolemy then invaded the country, and established garrisons throughout the cities; and on making himself master of Judea, set out for his daughter, and sent letters to Demetrius in the islands, saying, Come and meet me here, and I will give thee my daughter Cleopatra to wife, for Alexander has sought to kill me.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:182
verses.text: Demetrius came accordingly, and Ptolemy received him, and gave him her who had been destined for Alexander.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:183
verses.text: Thus is fulfilled that which is written: "And he shall corrupt her, and she shall not be his wife".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:184
verses.text: Alexander was slain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:185
verses.text: Then Ptolemy wore two crowns, that of Syria and that of Egypt, and died the third day after he had assumed them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:186
verses.text: Thus is fulfilled that which is written in Scripture: "And they shall not give him the glory of the kingdom".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:187
verses.text: For he died, and received not honour from all as king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:188
verses.text: The prophet then, after thus recounting the things which have taken place already, and been fulfilled in their times, declares yet another mystery to us, while he points out the last times.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:189
verses.text: For he says: "And there shall rise up another shameless king; and he shall exalt himself above every god, and shall magnify himself, and shall speak marvellous things, and shall prosper till the indignation be accomplished;" and so forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:190
verses.text: "And these shall escape out of his hand, Edom, and Moab, and the chief (or principality) of the children of Ammon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:191
verses.text: And he shall stretch forth his hand upon the land; and the land of Egypt shall not escape.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:192
verses.text: And he shall have power over the secret treasures of gold and silver, and over all the precious things of Egypt and of the Libyans, and the Ethiopians in their strongholds".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:193
verses.text: Thus, then, does the prophet set forth these things concerning the Antichrist, who shall be shameless, a war-maker, and despot, who, exalting himself above all kings and above every god, shall build the city of Jerusalem, and restore the sanctuary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:194
verses.text: Him the impious will worship as God, and will bend to him the knee, thinking him to be the Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:195
verses.text: He shall cut off the two witnesses and forerunners of Christ, who proclaim His glorious kingdom from heaven, as it is said: "And I will give (power) unto my two witnesses, and they shall prophesy a thousand two hundred and threescore days, clothed in sackcloth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:196
verses.text: As also it was announced to Daniel: "And one week shall confirm a covenant with many; and in the midst of the week it shall be that the sacrifice and oblation shall be removed"âthat the one week might be shown to be divided into two.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:197
verses.text: The two witnesses, then, shall preach three years and a half; and Antichrist shall make war upon the saints during the rest of the week, and desolate the world, that what is written may be fulfilled: "And they shall make the abomination of desolation for a thousand two hundred and ninety days".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:198
verses.text: Daniel has spoken, therefore, of two abominations; the one of destruction, and the other of desolation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:199
verses.text: What is that of destruction, but that which Antiochus established there at the time? And what is that of desolation, but that which shall be universal when Antichrist comes?  "And there shall escape out of his hand, Edom, and Moab, and the chief of the children of Ammon".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:200
verses.text: For these are they who ally themselves with him on account of their kinship, and first address him as king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:201
verses.text: Those of Edom are the sons of Esau, who inhabit Mount Seir.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:202
verses.text: And Moab and Ammon are they who are descended from his two daughters, as Isaiah also says: "And they shall fly (extend themselves) in the ships of strangers, and they shall also plunder the sea; and those from the east, and from the west, and the north, shall give them honour: and the children of Ammon shall first obey them".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:203
verses.text: He shall be proclaimed king by them, and shall be magnified by all, and shall prove himself an abomination of desolation to the world, and shall reign for a thousand two hundred and ninety days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:204
verses.text: "Blessed is he that waiteth, and cometh to the thousand three hundred and five and thirty days;" for when the abomination cometh and makes war upon the saints, whosoever shall survive his days, and reach the forty-five days, while the other period of fifty days advances, to him the kingdom of heaven comes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:205
verses.text: Antichrist, indeed, enters even into part of the fifty days, but the saints shall inherit the kingdom along with Christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:206
verses.text: These things being thus narrated, Daniel proceeds: "And, behold, there stood two men, the one on this side of the bank of the river, and the other on that side; and they made answer to the man that stood upon the bank of the river, and said to him, How long shall it be to the end of these wonderful words which thou hast spoken? And I heard the man clothed in linen, who was upon the water of the river; and he lifted up his right hand and his left hand unto heaven, and sware by Him that liveth for ever, that it shall be for a time, times, and an half; and they shall know all these things when the dispersion is accomplished".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:207
verses.text: Who, then, were the two men who stood on the bank of the river, but the law and the prophets? And who was he who stood upon the water, but He concerning whom they prophesied of old, who in the last times was to be borne witness to by the Father at the Jordan, and to be declared to the people boldly by John, "who wore the casty of the scribe about his loins, and was clothed with a linen coat of various colours?" These, therefore, interrogate Him, knowing that to Him were given all government and power, in order to learn accurately of Him when He will bring the judgment on the world, and when the things spoken by Him will be fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:208
verses.text: And He, desiring by all means to convince them, lifted His right hand and His left hand to heaven, and sware by Him that liveth for ever.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:209
verses.text: Who is He that swore, and by whom sware He? Manifestly the Son by the Father, saying, The Father liveth for ever, but in a time, and times, and an half, when the dispersion is accomplished, they shall know all these things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:210
verses.text: By the stretching forth of His two hands He signified His passion; and by mentioning "a time, and times, and an half, when the dispersion is accomplished," He indicated the three years and a half of Antichrist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:211
verses.text: For by "a time" He means a year, and by "times" two years, and by an "half time" half a year.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:212
verses.text: These are the thousand two hundred and ninety days of which Daniel prophesied for the finishing of the passion, and the accomplishment of the dispersion when Antichrist comes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:213
verses.text: In those days they shall know all these things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:214
verses.text: And from the time of the removal of the continuous sacrifice there are also reckoned one thousand two hundred and ninety days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:215
verses.text: (Then) iniquity shall abound, as the Lord also says:  "Because iniquity shall abound, the love of many shall wax cold".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:216
verses.text: And that divisions will arise when the falling away takes place, is without doubt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:217
verses.text: And when divisions arise, love is chilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:218
verses.text: The words, "Blessed is he that waiteth and cometh to the thousand three hundred and five and thirty days," have also their value, as the Lord said: "But he that shall endure unto the end, the same shall be saved".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:219
verses.text: Wherefore let us by no means admit the falling away, lest iniquity abound, and the abomination of desolationâthat is, the adversaryâovertake us.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:220
verses.text: And He said to him, "unto evening"âthat is, unto the consummationâ"and morning".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:221
verses.text: What is "morning?" The day of resurrection.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:222
verses.text: For that is the beginning of another age, as the morning is the beginning of the day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:223
verses.text: And the thousand and four hundred days are the light of the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:224
verses.text: For on the appearing of the light in the world (as He says, "I am the light of the world"), the sanctuary shall be purged, as he said, (of) the adversary.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 21:225
verses.text: For it cannot by any means be purged but by his destruction.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:1
verses.text: Scholia on Daniel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:2
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:3
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:4
verses.text: "In the third year of the reign of Jehoiakim".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:5
verses.text: The Scripture narrates these things, with the purpose of intimating the second captivity of the people, when Jehoiakim and the three youths with him, together with Daniel, were taken captive and carried off.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:6
verses.text: "And the Lord gave," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:7
verses.text: These words, "and the Lord gave," are written, that no one, in reading the introduction to the book, may attribute their capture to the strength of the captors and the slackness of their chief.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:8
verses.text: And it is well said, "with part," for the deportation was for the correction, not the ruin, of the whole nation, that there might be no misapplication of the cause.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:9
verses.text: "And Daniel purposed in his heart".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:10
verses.text: Oh, blessed are they who thus kept the covenant of the fathers, and transgressed not the law given by Moses, but feared the God proclaimed by him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:11
verses.text: These, though captives in a strange land, were not seduced by delicate meats, nor were they slaves to the pleasures of wine, nor were they caught by the bait of princely glory.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:12
verses.text: But they kept their mouth holy and pure, that pure speech might proceed from pure mouths, and praise with such (mouths) the heavenly Father.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:13
verses.text: "Prove now thy servants".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:14
verses.text: They teach that it is not earthly meats that give to men their beauty and strength, but the grace of God bestowed by the Word.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:15
verses.text: "And after a little".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:16
verses.text: Thou hast seen the incorruptible faith of the youths, and the unalterable fear of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:17
verses.text: They asked an interval of ten days, to prove therein that man cannot otherwise find grace with God than by believing the word preached by the Lord.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:18
verses.text: "And among them all, was found none like Daniel".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:19
verses.text: These men, who were proved faithful witnesses in Babylon, were led by the Word in all wisdom, that by their means the idols of the Babylonians should be put to shame, and that Nebuchadnezzar should be overcome by three youths, and that by their faith the fire in the furnace should be kept at bay, and the desire of the wicked elders (or chiefs) proved vain.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:20
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:21
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:22
verses.text: "I have dreamed a dream".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:23
verses.text: The dream, then, which was seen by the king was not an earthly dream, so that it might be interpreted by the wise of the world; but it was a heavenly dream, fulfilled in its proper times, according to the counsel and foreknowledge of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:24
verses.text: And for this reason it was kept secret from men who think of earthly things, that to those who seek after heavenly things heavenly mysteries might be revealed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:25
verses.text: And, indeed, there was a similar case in Egypt in the time of Pharaoh and Joseph.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:26
verses.text: "The thing is gone from me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:27
verses.text: For this purpose was the vision concealed from the king, that he who was chosen of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:28
verses.text: , viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:29
verses.text: , Daniel, might be shown to be a prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:30
verses.text: For when things concealed from some are revealed by another, he who tells them is of necessity shown to be a prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:31
verses.text: "And they say, There is not a man".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:32
verses.text: Whereas, therefore, they declared it to be impossible that what was asked by the king should be told by man; God showed them, that what is impossible with man is possible with God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:33
verses.text: "Arioch, the captain of the king's guard" (literally, "the chief slaughterer or cook").

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:34
verses.text: For as the cook slays all animals and cooks them, of a similar nature was his occupation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:35
verses.text: And the rulers of the world slay men, butchering them like brute beasts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:36
verses.text: "Because Thou hast given me wisdom and might".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:37
verses.text: We ought therefore to mark the goodness of God, how He straightway reveals and shows (Himself) to the worthy, and to those that fear Him, fulfilling their prayers and supplications, as the prophet says: "Who is wise, and he shall understand these things? and prudent, and he shall know them?".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:38
verses.text: "Cannot the wise men, the magicians".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:39
verses.text: He instructs the king not to seek an explanation of heavenly mysteries from earthly men, for they shall be accomplished in their due time by God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:40
verses.text: "As for thee, O king, thy thoughts".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:41
verses.text: For the king, on making himself master of the land of Egypt, and getting hold of the country of Judea, and carrying off the people, thought upon his bed what should be after these things; and He who knows the secrets of all, and searcheth the thoughts of the hearts, revealed to him by means of the image the things that were to be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:42
verses.text: And He hid from him the vision, in order that the counsels of God might not be interpreted by the wise men of Babylon, but that by the blessed Daniel, as a prophet of God, things kept secret from all might be made manifest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:43
verses.text: "Behold a great image".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:44
verses.text: How, then, should we not mark the things prophesied of old in Babylon by Daniel, and now yet in the course of fulfilment in the world? For the image shown at that time to Nebuchadnezzar furnished a type of the whole world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:45
verses.text: In these times the Babylonians were sovereign over all, and these were the golden head of the image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:46
verses.text: And then, after them, the Persians held the supremacy for  years, and they were represented by the silver.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:47
verses.text: Then the Greeks had the supremacy, beginning with Alexander of Macedon, for  years, so that they were the brass.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:48
verses.text: After them came the Romans, who were the iron legs of the image, for they were strong as iron.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:49
verses.text: Then (we have) the toes of clay and iron, to signify the democracies that were subsequently to rise, partitioned among the ten toes of the image, in which shall be iron mixed with clay.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:50
verses.text: "Thou sawest," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:51
verses.text: Apollinaris on this: He looked, and behold, as it were, an image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:52
verses.text: For it did not appear to him as an actual object, presented to the view of an onlooker, but as an image or semblance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:53
verses.text: And while it contains in it many things together, that is in such a way that it is not really one, but manifold.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:54
verses.text: For it comprised a summary of all kingdoms; and its exceeding splendour was on account of the glory of the kings, and its terrible appearance on account of their power.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:55
verses.text: Eusebius Pamphili, and Hippolytus the most holy bishop of Rome, compare the dream of Nebuchadnezzar now in question with the vision of the prophet Daniel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:56
verses.text: Since these have given a different interpretation of this vision now before us in their expositions, I deemed it necessary to transcribe what is said by Eusebius of Caesarea, who bears the surname Pamphili, in the th book of his Gospel Demonstration; for he expounds the whole vision in these terms: "I think that this (i-e:, the vision of Nebuchadnezzar) differs in nothing from the vision of the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:57
verses.text: For as the prophet saw a great sea, so the king saw a great image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:58
verses.text: And again, as the prophet saw four beasts, which he interpreted as four kingdoms, so the king was given to understand four kingdoms under the gold, and silver, and brass, and iron.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:59
verses.text: And again, as the prophet saw the division of the ten horns of the last beast, and three horns broken by one; so the king, in like manner, saw in the extremities of the image one part iron and another clay.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:60
verses.text: And besides this, as the prophet, after the vision of the four kingdoms, saw the Son of man receive dominion, and power, and a kingdom; so also the king thought he saw a stone smite the whole image, and become a great mountain and fill the sea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:61
verses.text: And rightly so.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:62
verses.text: For it was quite consistent in the king, whose view of the spectacle of life was so false, and who admired the beauty of the mere sensible colours, so to speak, in the picture set up to view, to liken the life of all men to a great image; but (it became) the prophet to compare the great and mighty tumult of life to a mighty sea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:63
verses.text: And it was fitting that the king, who prized the substances deemed precious among men, gold, and silver, and brass, and iron, should liken to these substances the kingdoms that held the sovereignty at different times in the life of men; but that the prophet should describe these same kingdoms under the likeness of beasts, in accordance with the manner of their rule.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:64
verses.text: And again, the kingâwho was puffed up, as it seems, in his own conceit, and plumed himself on the power of his ancestorsâis shown the vicissitude to which affairs are subject, and the end destined for all the kingdoms of earth, with the view of teaching him to lay aside his pride in himself, and understand that there is nothing stable among men, but only that which is the appointed end of all thingsâthe kingdom of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:65
verses.text: For after the first kingdom of the Assyrians, which was denoted by the gold, there will be the second kingdom of the Persians, expressed by the silver; and then the third kingdom of the Macedonians, signified by the brass; and after it, the fourth kingdom of the Romans will succeed, more powerful than those that went before it; for which reason also it was likened to iron.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:66
verses.text: For of it is said: "And the fourth kingdom shall be strong as iron; as iron breaketh and subdueth all things, so shall it break and subdue all things".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:67
verses.text: And after all these kingdoms which have been mentioned, the kingdom of God is represented by the stone that breaks the whole image.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:68
verses.text: And the prophet, in conformity with this, does not see the kingdom which comes at the end of all these things, until he has in order described the four dominions mentioned under the four beasts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:69
verses.text: And I think that the visions shown, both to the king and to the prophet, were visions of these four kingdoms alone, and of none others, because by these the nation of the Jews was held in bondage from the times of the prophet".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:70
verses.text: "His feet," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:71
verses.text: Hippolytus: In the vision of the prophet, the ten horns are the things that are yet to be.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:72
verses.text: "Thou sawest till that a stone was cut".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:73
verses.text: Thou sawest, as it were, a stone cut without hands, and smiting the image upon its feet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:74
verses.text: For the human kingdom was decisively separated from the divine; with reference to which it is written, "as it were cut".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:75
verses.text: The stroke, however, smites the extremities, and in these it broke all dominion that is upon earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:76
verses.text: "And the dream is certain".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:77
verses.text: That no one, therefore, may have any doubt whether the things announced shall turn out so or not, the prophet has confirmed them with the words, "And the dream is certain, and the interpretation thereof sure;" I have not erred in the interpretation of the vision.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:78
verses.text: "Then king Nebuchadnezzar fell upon his face".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:79
verses.text: Nebuchadnezzar hearing these things, and being put in remembrance of his vision, knew that what was spoken by Daniel was true.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:80
verses.text: How great is the power of the grace of God, beloved, that one who a little before was doomed to death with the other wise men of Babylon, should now be worshipped by the king, not as man, but as God! "He commanded that they should offer manaa" (i-e:, in Chaldee, "oblation") "and sweet odours unto him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:81
verses.text: Of old, too, the Lord made a similar announcement to Moses, saying, "See, I have made thee a god to Pharaoh;" in order that, on account of the signs wrought by him in the land of Egypt, Moses might no longer be reckoned a man, but be worshipped as a god by the Egyptians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:82
verses.text: "Then the king made Daniel a great man".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:83
verses.text: For as he had humbled himself, and presented himself as the least among all men, God made him great, and the king established him as ruler over the whole land of Babylon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:84
verses.text: Just as also Pharaoh did to Joseph, appointing him then to be ruler over the whole land of Egypt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:85
verses.text: "And Daniel requested," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:86
verses.text: For as they had united with Daniel in prayer to God that the vision might be revealed to him, so Daniel, when he obtained great honour from the king, made mention of them, explaining to the king what had been done by them, in order that they also should be deemed worthy of some honour as fellow-seers and worshippers of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:87
verses.text: For when they asked heavenly things from the Lord, they received also earthly things from the king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:88
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:89
verses.text: iii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:90
verses.text: "In the eighteenth year," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:91
verses.text: (These words are wanting in the Vulgate, etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:92
verses.text: ) A considerable space of time having elapsed, therefore, and the eighteenth year being now in its course, the king, calling to mind his vision, "made an image of gold, whose height was threescore cubits, and the breadth thereof six cubits".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:93
verses.text: For as the blessed Daniel, in interpreting the vision, had answered the king, saying, "Thou art this head of gold in the image," the king, being puffed up with this address, and elated in heart, made a copy of this image, in order that he might be worshipped by all as God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:94
verses.text: "All the people fell".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:95
verses.text: Some (did so) because they feared the king himself; but all (or "most"), because they were idolaters, obeyed the word commanded by the king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:96
verses.text: "Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego answered," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:97
verses.text: These three youths are become an example to all faithful men, inasmuch as they did not fear the crowd of satraps, neither did they tremble when they heard the king's words, nor did they shrink when they saw the flame of the blazing furnace, but deemed all men and the whole world as nought, and kept the fear of God alone before their eyes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:98
verses.text: Daniel, though he stood at a distance and kept silence, encouraged them to be of good cheer as he smiled to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:99
verses.text: And he rejoiced also himself at the witness they bore, understanding, as he did, that the three youths would receive a crown in triumph over the devil.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:100
verses.text: "And commanded that they should heat the furnace one seven times more".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:101
verses.text: He bids the vast furnace be heated one seven times more, as if he were already overcome by them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:102
verses.text: In earthly things, then, the king was superior; but in faith toward God the three youths were superior.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:103
verses.text: Tell me, Nebuchadnezzar, with what purpose you order them to be cast into the fire bound? Is it lest they might escape, if they should have their feet unbound, and thus be able to extinguish the fire? But thou doest not these things of thyself, but there is another who worketh these things by thy means.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:104
verses.text: "And the flame streamed forth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:105
verses.text: The fire, he means, was driven from within by the angel, and burst forth outwardly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:106
verses.text: See how even the fire appears intelligent, as if it recognised and punished the guilty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:107
verses.text: For it did not touch the servants of God, but it consumed the unbelieving and impious Chaldeans.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:108
verses.text: Those who were within were besprinkled with a (cooling) dew by the angel, while those who thought they stood in safety outside the furnace were destroyed by the fire.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:109
verses.text: The men who cast in the youths were burned by the flame, which caught them on all sides, as I suppose, when they went to bind the youths.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:110
Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:111
verses.text: "And the form of the fourth is like the Son of God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:112
verses.text: Tell me, Nebuchadnezzar, when didst thou see the Son of God, that thou shouldst confess that this is the Son of God? And who pricked thy heart, that thou shouldst utter such a word? And with what eyes wert thou able to look into this light? And why was this manifested to thee alone, and to none of the satraps about thee? But, as it is written, "The heart of a king is in the hand of God:" the hand of God is here, whereby the Word pricked his heart, so that he might recognise Him in the furnace, and glorify Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:113
verses.text: And this idea of ours is not without good ground.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:114
verses.text: For as the children of Israel were destined to see God in the world, and yet not to believe on Him, the Scripture showed beforehand that the Gentiles would recognise Him incarnate, whom, while not incarnate, Nebuchadnezzar saw and recognised of old in the furnace, and acknowledged to be the Son of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:115
Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:116
verses.text: "And he said, Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:117
verses.text: The three youths he thus called by name.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:118
verses.text: But he found no name by which to call the fourth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:119
verses.text: For He was not yet that Jesus born of the Virgin.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:120
Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:121
verses.text: "Then the king promoted," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:122
verses.text: For as they honoured God by giving themselves up to death, so, too, they were themselves honoured not only by God, but also by the king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:123
verses.text: And they taught strange and foreign nations also to worship God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:124
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:125
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:126
verses.text: "And he wrote the dream".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:127
verses.text: The things, therefore, which were revealed to the blessed prophet by the Spirit in visions, these he also recounted fully for others, that he might not appear to prophesy of the future to himself alone, but might be proved a prophet to others also, who wish to search the divine Scriptures.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:128
verses.text: "And behold the four winds".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:129
verses.text: He means created existence in its fourfold division.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:130
verses.text: "And four great beasts".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:131
verses.text: As various beasts then were shown to the blessed Daniel, and these different from each other, we should understand that the truth of the narrative deals not with certain beasts, but, under the type and image of different beasts, exhibits the kingdoms that have risen in this world in power over the race of man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:132
verses.text: For by the great sea he means the whole world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:133
verses.text: "Till the wings thereof were plucked".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:134
verses.text: For this happened in reality in the time of Nebuchadnezzar, as has been shown in the preceding book.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:135
verses.text: And he bears witness directly that this very thing was fulfilled in himself; for he was driven out of the kingdom, and stripped of his glory, and of the greatness which he formerly possessed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:136
verses.text: "And after a little:" the words, "It was made stand upon the feet as a man, and a man's heart was given to it," signify that Nebuchadnezzar, when he humbled himself, and acknowledged that he was but a man, in subjection under the power of God, and made supplication to the Lord, found mercy with Him, and was restored to his own kingdom and honour.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:137
verses.text: "A second beast like to a bear".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:138
verses.text: To represent the kingdom of the Persians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:139
verses.text: "And it had three ribs".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:140
verses.text: The three nations he calls three ribs.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:141
verses.text: The meaning, therefore, is this: that beast had the dominion, and these others under it were the Medes, Assyrians, and Babylonians.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:142
verses.text: "And they said thus to it, Arise, devour".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:143
verses.text: For the Persians arising in these times, devastated every land, and made many men subject to them, and slew them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:144
verses.text: For as this beast, the bear, is a foul animal, and carnivorous, tearing with claws and teeth, such also was the kingdom of the Persians, who held the supremacy for two hundred and thirty years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:145
verses.text: "And, lo, another beast like a leopard".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:146
verses.text: In mentioning a leopard, he means the kingdom of the Greeks, over whom Alexander of Macedon was king.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:147
verses.text: And he likened them to a leopard, because they were quick and inventive in thought, and bitter in heart, just as that animal is many-coloured in appearance, and quick in wounding and in drinking man's blood.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:148
verses.text: "The beast had also four heads".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:149
verses.text: When the kingdom of Alexander was exalted, and grew, and acquired a name over the whole world, his kingdom was divided into four principalities.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:150
verses.text: For Alexander, when near his end, partitioned his kingdom among his four comrades of the same race, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:151
verses.text: , "Seleucus, Demetrius, Ptolemy, and Philip;" and all these assumed crowns, as Daniel prophesies, and as it is written in the first book of Maccabees.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:152
verses.text: "And behold a fourth beast".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:153
verses.text: Now, that there has arisen no other kingdom after that of the Greeks except that which stands sovereign at present, is manifest to all.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:154
verses.text: This one has iron teeth, because it subdues and reduces all by its strength, just as iron does.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:155
verses.text: And the rest it did tread with its feet, for there is no other kingdom remaining after this one, but from it will spring ten horns.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:156
verses.text: "And it had ten horns".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:157
verses.text: For as the prophet said already of the leopard, that the beast had four heads, and that was fulfilled, and Alexander's kingdom was divided into four principalities, so also now we ought to look for the ten horns which are to spring from it, when the time of the beast shall be fulfilled, and the little horn, which is Antichrist, shall appear suddenly in their midst, and righteousness shall be banished from the earth, and the whole world shall reach its consummation.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:158
verses.text: So that we ought not to anticipate the counsel of God, but exercise patience and prayer, that we fall not on such times.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:159
verses.text: We should not, however, refuse to believe that these things will come to pass.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:160
verses.text: For if the things which the prophets predicted in former times have not been realized, then we need not look for these things.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:161
verses.text: But if those former things did happen in their proper seasons, as was foretold, these things also shall certainly be fulfilled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:162
verses.text: "I considered the horns".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:163
verses.text: That is to say, I looked intently at the beast, and was astonished at everything about it, but especially at the number of the horns.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:164
verses.text: For the appearance of this beast differed from that of the other beasts in kind.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:165
verses.text: "And came to the Ancient of days".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:166
verses.text: By the Ancient of days he means none other than the Lord and God and Ruler of all, and even of Christ Himself, who maketh the days old, and yet becometh not old Himself by times and days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:167
verses.text: "His dominion is an everlasting dominion".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:168
verses.text: The Father, having put all things in subjection to His own Son, both things in heaven and things on earth, showed Him forth by all as the first-begotten of God, in order that, along with the Father, He might be approved the Son of God before angels, and be manifested as the Lord also of angels: (He showed Him forth also as) the first-begotten of a virgin, that He might be seen to be in Himself the Creator anew of the first-formed Adam, (and) as the first-begotten from the dead, that He might become Himself the first-fruits of our resurrection.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:169
verses.text: "Which shall not pass away".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:170
verses.text: He exhibited all the dominion given by the Father to His own Son, who is manifested as King of all in heaven and on earth, and under the earth, and as Judge of all: of all in heaven, because He was born the Word, of the heart of the Father before all; and of all in earth, because He was made man, and created Adam anew of Himself; and of all under the earth, because He was also numbered among the dead, and preached to the souls of the saints, (and) by death overcame death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:171
verses.text: "Which shall arise".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:172
verses.text: For when the three beasts have finished their course, and been removed, and the one still stands in vigour,âif this one, too, is removed, then finally earthly things (shall) end, and heavenly things begin; that the indissoluble and everlasting kingdom of the saints may be brought to view, and the heavenly King manifested to all, no longer in figure, like one seen in vision, or revealed in a pillar of cloud upon the top of a mountain, but amid the powers and armies of angels, as God incarnate and man, Son of God and Son of manâcoming from heaven as the world's Judge.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:173
verses.text: "And I inquired about the fourth beast".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:174
verses.text: It is to the fourth kingdom, of which we have already spoken, that he here refers:  that kingdom, than which no greater kingdom of like nature has arisen upon the earth; from which also ten horns are to spring, and to be apportioned among ten crowns.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:175
verses.text: And amid these another little horn shall rise, which is that of Antichrist.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:176
verses.text: And it shall pluck by the roots the three others before it; that is to say, he shall subvert the three kings of Egypt, Libya, and Ethiopia, with the view of acquiring for himself universal dominion.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:177
verses.text: And after conquering the remaining seven horns, he will at last begin, inflated by a strange and wicked spirit, to stir up war against the saints, and to persecute all everywhere, with the aim of being glorified by all, and being worshipped as God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:178
verses.text: "Until the Ancient of days come".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:179
verses.text: That is, when at length the Judge of judges and the King of kings comes from heaven, who shall subvert the whole dominion and power of the adversary, and shall consume all with the eternal fire of punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:180
verses.text: But to His servants, and prophets, and martyrs, and to all who fear Him, He will give an everlasting kingdom; that is, they shall possess the endless enjoyment of good.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:181
verses.text: "Until a time, and times, and the dividing of time".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:182
verses.text: This denotes three years and a half.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:183
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:184
verses.text: ix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:185
verses.text: "And, behold, the man Gabrielâ¦flying".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:186
verses.text: You see how the prophet likens the speed of the angels to a winged bird, on account of the light and rapid motion with which these spirits fly so quickly in discharge of orders.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:187
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:188
verses.text: x.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:189
verses.text: "And the voice of His words".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:190
verses.text: For all we who now believe on Him declare the words of Christ, as if we spake by His mouth the things enjoined by Him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:191
verses.text: "And I saw," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:192
verses.text: For it is to His saints that fear Him, and to them alone, that He reveals Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:193
verses.text: For if any one seems to be living now in the Church, and yet has not the fear of God, his companionship with the saints will avail him nothing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:194
verses.text: "Thy words were heard".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:195
verses.text: Behold how much the piety of a righteous man availeth, that to him alone, as to one worthy, things not yet to be manifested in the world should be revealed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:196
verses.text: "And lo, Michael".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:197
verses.text: Who is Michael but the angel assigned to the people? As (God) says to Moses, "I will not go with you in the way, because the people are stiff-necked; but my angel shall go with you".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:198
verses.text: "My inwards are turned" (A.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:199
verses.text: V.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:200
verses.text: , "my sorrows are turned upon me").

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:201
verses.text: For it was meet that, at the appearing of the Lord, what was above should be turned beneath, in order that also what was beneath might come above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:202
verses.text: âI require time, he says, to recover myself, and to be able to endure the words and to make reply to what is said.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:203
verses.text: âBut while I was in this position, he continues, I was strengthened beyond my hope.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:204
verses.text: For one unseen touched me, and straightway my weakness was removed, and I was restored to my former strength.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:205
verses.text: For whenever all the strength of our life and its glory pass from us, then are we strengthened by Christ, who stretches forth His hand and raises the living from among the dead, and as it were from Hades itself, to the resurrection of life.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:206
verses.text: "And he strengthened me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:207
verses.text: For whenever the Word has made us of good hope with regard to the future, we are able also readily to hear His voice.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:208
verses.text: "To fight with the prince of Persia".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:209
verses.text: For from the day that thou didst humble thyself before the Lord thy God thy prayer was heard, and I was sent "to fight with the prince of Persia".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:210
verses.text: For there was a design not to let the people go.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:211
verses.text: Therefore, that thy prayer might be speedily answered, "I stood up against him".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:212
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:213
verses.text: xii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:214
verses.text: "There shall be a time of trouble".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:215
verses.text: For at that time there shall be great trouble, such as has not been from the foundation of the world, when some in one way, and others in another, shall be sent through every city and country to destroy the faithful; and the saints shall travel from the west to the east, and shall be driven in persecution from the east to the south, while others shall conceal themselves in the mountains and caves; and the abomination shall war against them everywhere, and shall cut them off by sea and by land by his decree, and shall endeavour by every means to destroy them out of the world; and they shall not be able any longer to sell their own property, nor to buy from strangers, unless one keeps and carries with him the name of the beast, or bears its mark upon his forehead.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:216
verses.text: For then they shall all be driven out from every place, and dragged from their own homes and haled into prison, and punished with all manner of punishment, and cast out from the whole world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:217
verses.text: "These shall awake to everlasting life".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:218
verses.text: That is, those who have believed in the true life, and who have their names written in the book of life.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:219
verses.text: "And these to shame".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:220
verses.text: That is, those who are attached to Antichrist, and who are cast with him into everlasting punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:221
verses.text: "And they that be wise shall shine".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:222
verses.text: And the Lord has said the same thing in the Gospel: "Then shall the righteous shine forth as the sun".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:223
verses.text: "For a time, times, and an half".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:224
verses.text: By this he indicated the three and a half years of Anti-christ.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:225
verses.text: For by a time he means a year; and by times, two years; and by an half time, half a year.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:226
verses.text: These are the "one thousand two hundred and ninety days" of which Daniel prophesied.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:227
verses.text: "The words are closed up and sealed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:228
verses.text: For as a man cannot tell what God has prepared for the saints; for neither has eye seen nor ear heard, nor has it entered into the heart of man (to conceive) these things, into which even the saints, too, shall then eagerly desire to look; so He said to him, "For the words are sealed until the time of the end; until many shall be chosen and tried with fire".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:229
verses.text: And who are they who are chosen, but those who believe the word of truth, so as to be made white thereby, and to cast off the filth of sin, and put on the heavenly, pure, and glorious Holy Spirit, in order that, when the Bridegroom comes, they may go in straightway with Him?.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:230
verses.text: "The abomination of desolation shall be given (set up)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:231
verses.text: Daniel speaks, therefore, of two abominations: the one of destruction, which Antiochus set up in its appointed time, and which bears a relation to that of desolation, and the other universal, when Antichrist shall come.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 22:232
verses.text: For, as Daniel says, he too shall be set up for the destruction of many.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 23

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 23:1
verses.text: Other Fragments on Daniel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 23:2
verses.text: For when the iron legs that now hold the sovereignty have given place to the feet and the toes, in accordance with the representation of the terrible beast, as has also been signified in the former times, then from heaven will come the stone that smites the image, and breaks it; and it will subvert all the kingdoms, and give the kingdom to the saints of the Most High.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 23:3
verses.text: This is the stone which becomes a great mountain, and fills the earth, and of which it is written: "I saw in the night-visions, and, behold, one like the Son of man came with the clouds of heaven, and came to the Ancient of days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 23:4
verses.text: And there was given Him dominion, and glory, and a kingdom; and all peoples, nations, and languages shall serve Him: His power is an everlasting power, which shall not pass away, and His kingdom shall not be destroyed".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 24

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 24:1
verses.text: On the Song of the Three Children.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 24:2
verses.text: "O Ananias, Azarias, and Misael, bless ye the Lord; O ye apostles, prophets, and martyrs of the Lord, bless ye the Lord: praise Him, and exalt Him above all, for ever".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 24:3
verses.text: We may well marvel at the words of the three youths in the furnace, how they enumerated all created things, so that not one of them might be reckoned free and independent in itself; but, summing up and naming them all together, both things in heaven, and things in earth, and things under the earth, they showed them to be all the servants of God, who created all things by the Word, that no one should boast that any of the creatures was without birth and beginning.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:1
verses.text: On Susannah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:2
verses.text: What is narrated here, happened at a later time, although it is placed before the first book (at the beginning of the book).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:3
verses.text: For it was a custom with the writers to narrate many things in an inverted order in their writings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:4
verses.text: For we find also in the prophets some visions recorded among the first and fulfilled among the last; and again, on the other hand, some recorded among the last and fulfilled first.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:5
verses.text: And this was done by the disposition of the Spirit, that the devil might not understand the things spoken in parables by the prophets, and might not a second time lay his snares and ruin man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:6
verses.text: Ver.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:7
verses.text: "Called Joacim".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:8
verses.text: This Joacim, being a stranger in Babylon, obtains Susannah in marriage.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:9
verses.text: And she was the daughter of Chelcias the priest, who found the book of the law in the house of the Lord, when Josiah the king commanded him to purify the holy of holies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:10
verses.text: His brother was Jeremiah the prophet, who was carried, with the remnant that was left after the deportation of the people to Babylon, into Egypt, and dwelt in Taphnae; and, while prophesying there, he was stoned to death by the people.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:11
verses.text: "A very fair woman, and one that feared the Lord," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:12
verses.text: For by the fruit produced, the tree also is easily known.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:13
verses.text: For men who are pious and zealous for the law, bring into the world children worthy of God; such as he was who became a prophet and witness of Christ, and she who was found chaste and faithful in Babylon, whose honour and chastity were the occasion of the manifestation of the blessed Daniel as a prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:14
verses.text: "Now Joacim was a great rich man," etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:15
verses.text: We must therefore seek the explanation of this.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:16
verses.text: For how could those who were captives, and had been made subject to the Babylonians, meet together in the same place, as if they were their own masters? In this matter, therefore, we should observe that Nebuchadnezzar, after their deportation, treated them kindly, and permitted them to meet together, and do all things according to the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:17
verses.text: "And at noon Susannah went into (her husband's garden)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:18
verses.text: Susannah prefigured the Church; and Joacim, her husband, Christ; and the garden, the calling of the saints, who are planted like fruitful trees in the Church.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:19
verses.text: And Babylon is the world; and the two elders are set forth as a figure of the two peoples that plot against the Churchâthe one, namely, of the circumcision, and the other of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:20
verses.text: For the words, "were appointed rulers of the people and judges," (mean) that in this world they exercise authority and rule, judging the righteous unrighteously.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:21
verses.text: "And the two elders saw her".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:22
verses.text: These things the rulers of the Jews wish now to expunge from the book, and assert that these things did not happen in Babylon, because they are ashamed of what was done then by the elders.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:23
verses.text: "And they perverted their own mind".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:24
verses.text: For how, indeed, can those who have been the enemies and corruptors of the Church judge righteously, or look up to heaven with pure heart, when they have become the slaves of the prince of this world?.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:25
verses.text: "And they were both wounded with her (love)".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:26
verses.text: This word is to be taken in truth; for always the two peoples, being wounded (instigated) by Satan working in them, strive to raise persecutions and afflictions against the Church, and seek how they may corrupt her, though they do not agree with each other.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:27
verses.text: "And they watched diligently".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:28
verses.text: And this, too, is to be noted.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:29
verses.text: For up to the present time both the Gentiles and the Jews of the circumcision watch and busy themselves with the dealings of the Church, desiring to suborn false witnesses against us, as the apostle says:  "And that because of false brethren unawares brought in, who came in privily to spy out our liberty which we have in Christ Jesus".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:30
verses.text: It is a kind of sin to be anxious to give the mind to women.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:31
verses.text: "And when they were gone out, they parted the one from the other".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:32
verses.text: As to their parting the one from the other at the hour of dinner (luncheon), this signifies that in the matter of earthly meats the Jews and the Gentiles are not at one; but in their views, and in all worldly matters, they are of one mind, and can meet each other.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:33
verses.text: "And asking one another, they acknowledged their lust".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:34
verses.text: Thus, in revealing themselves to each other, they foreshadow the time when they shall be proved by their thoughts, and shall have to give account to God for all the sin which they have done, as Solomon says: "And scrutiny shall destroy the ungodly".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:35
verses.text: For these are convicted by the scrutiny.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:36
verses.text: "As they watched a fit time".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:37
verses.text: What fit time but that of the passover, at which the laver is prepared in the garden for those who burn, and Susannah washes herself, and is presented as a pure bride to God?  "With two maids only".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:38
verses.text: For when the Church desires to take the laver according to use, she must of necessity have two handmaids to accompany her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:39
verses.text: For it is by faith on Christ and love to God that the Church confesses and receives the laver.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:40
verses.text: "And she said to her maids, Bring me oil".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:41
verses.text: For faith and love prepare oil and unguents to those who are washed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:42
verses.text: But what were these unguents, but the commandments of the holy Word? And what was the oil, but the power of the Holy Spirit, with which believers are anointed as with ointment after the laver of washing? All these things were figuratively represented in the blessed Susannah, for our sakes, that we who now believe on God might not regard the things that are done now in the Church as strange, but believe them all to have been set forth in figure by the patriarchs of old, as the apostle also says:  "Now these things happened unto them for ensamples: and they were written for our instruction, on whom the ends of the world are come".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:43
verses.text: "And they went out at privy doors;" showing thus by anticipation, that he who desires to partake of the water in the garden must renounce the broad gate, and enter by the strait and narrow.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:44
verses.text: "And they saw not the elders".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:45
verses.text: For as of old the devil was concealed in the serpent in the garden, so now too, concealed in the elders, he fired them with his own lust, that he might again a second time corrupt Eve.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:46
verses.text: "Behold, the garden doors are shut".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:47
verses.text: O wicked rulers, and filled with the workings of the devil, did Moses deliver these things to you? And while ye read the law yourselves, do ye teach others thus? Thou that sayest, "Thou shalt not kill," dost thou kill? Thou that sayest, "Thou shalt not covet," dost thou desire to corrupt the wife of thy neighbour?  "And we are in love with thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:48
verses.text: Why, ye lawless, do ye strive to gain over a chaste and guileless soul by deceitful words, in order to satisfy your own lust?.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:49
verses.text: "If thou wilt not, we will bear witness against thee".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:50
verses.text: This wicked audacity with which you begin, comes of the deceitfulness that lurks in you from the beginning.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:51
verses.text: And there was in reality a young man with her, that one of yours; one from heaven, not to have intercourse with her, but to bear witness to her truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:52
verses.text: "And Susannah sighed".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:53
verses.text: The blessed Susannah, then, when she heard these words, was troubled in her heart, and set a watch upon her mouth, not wishing to be defiled by the wicked elders.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:54
verses.text: Now it is in our power also to apprehend the real meaning of all that befell Susannah.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:55
verses.text: For you may find this also fulfilled in the present condition of the Church.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:56
verses.text: For when the two peoples conspire to destroy any of the saints, they watch for a fit time, and enter the house of God while all there are praying and praising God, and seize some of them, and carry them off, and keep hold of them, saying, Come, consent with us, and worship our Gods; and if not, we will bear witness against you.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:57
verses.text: And when they refuse, they drag them before the court and accuse them of acting contrary to the decrees of Caesar, and condemn them to death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:58
verses.text: "I am straitened on every side".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:59
verses.text: Behold the words of a chaste woman, and one dear to God: "I am straitened on every side".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:60
verses.text: For the Church is afflicted and straitened, not only by the Jews, but also by the Gentiles, and by those who are called Christians, but are not such in reality.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:61
verses.text: For they, observing her chaste and happy life, strive to ruin her.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:62
verses.text: "For if I do this thing, it is death to me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:63
verses.text: For to be disobedient to God, and obedient to men, works eternal death and punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:64
verses.text: "And if I do it not, I cannot escape your hands".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:65
verses.text: And this indeed is said with truth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:66
verses.text: For they who are brought into judgment for the sake of God's name, if they do what is commanded them by men, die to God, and shall live in the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:67
verses.text: But if they refuse to do what is commanded them by men, they escape not the hands of their judges, but are condemned by them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:68
verses.text: "It is better for me not to do it".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:69
verses.text: For it is better to die by the hand of wicked men and live with God, than, by consenting to them, to be delivered from them and fall into the hands of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:70
verses.text: "And Susannah cried with a loud voice".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:71
verses.text: And to whom did Susannah cry but to God? as Isaiah says: "Then shalt thou call, and the Lord shall answer thee; whilst thou art yet speaking, He shall say, Lo, here I am".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:72
verses.text: "And the two elders cried out against her".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:73
verses.text: For the wicked never cease to cry out against us, and to say: Away with such from off the earth, for it is not fit that they should live.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:74
verses.text: In an evangelical sense, Susannah despised them who kill the body, in order that she might save her soul from death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:75
verses.text: Now sin is the death of the soul, and especially (the sin of) adultery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:76
verses.text: For when the soul that is united with Christ forsakes its faith, it is given over to perpetual death, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:77
