verses.text: , eternal punishment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:78
verses.text: And in confirmation of this, in the case of the transgression and violation of marriage unions in the flesh, the law has decreed the penalty of death.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:79
verses.text: "Then ran the one and opened the gates;" pointing to the broad and spacious way on which they who follow such persons perish.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:80
verses.text: "Now Susannah was a very delicate woman".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:81
verses.text: Not that she had meretricious adornments about her person, as Jezebel had, or eyes painted with divers colours; but that she had the adornment of faith, and chastity, and sanctity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:82
verses.text: "And laid their hands upon her head;" that at least by touching her they might satisfy their lust.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:83
verses.text: "And she was weeping".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:84
verses.text: For by her tears she attracted the (regard of) the Word from heaven, who was with tears to raise the dead Lazarus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:85
verses.text: "Then the assembly believed them".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:86
verses.text: It becomes us, then, to be stedfast in every duty, and to give no heed to lies, and to yield no obsequious obedience to the persons of rulers, knowing that we have to give account to God; but if we follow the truth, and aim at the exact rule of faith, we shall be well-pleasing to God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:87
verses.text: "And the Lord heard her voice".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:88
verses.text: For those who call upon Him from a pure heart, God heareth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:89
verses.text: But from those who (call upon Him) in deceit and hypocrisy, God turneth away His face.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:90
verses.text: "O thou that art waxen old in wickedness".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:91
verses.text: Now, since at the outset, in the introduction, we explained that the two elders are to be taken as a type of the two peoples, that of the circumcision and that of the Gentiles, which are always enemies of the Church; let us mark the words of Daniel, and learn that the Scripture deals falsely with us in nothing.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:92
verses.text: For, addressing the first elder, he censures him as one instructed in the law; while he addresses the other as a Gentile, calling him "the seed of Chanaan," although he was then among the circumcision.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:93
verses.text: "For even now the angel of God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:94
verses.text: He shows also, that when Susannah prayed to God, and was heard, the angel was sent then to help her, just as was the case in the instance of Tobias and Sara.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:95
verses.text: For when they prayed, the supplication of both of them was heard in the same day and the same hour, and the angel Raphael was sent to heal them both.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:96
verses.text: "And they arose against the two elders;" that the saying might be fulfilled, "Whoso diggeth a pit for his neighbour, shall fall therein".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:97
verses.text: To all these things, therefore, we ought to give heed, beloved, fearing lest any one be overtaken in any transgression, and risk the loss of his soul, knowing as we do that God is the Judge of all; and the Word Himself is the Eye which nothing that is done in the world escapes.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 25:98
verses.text: Therefore, always watchful in heart and pure in life, let us imitate Susannah.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 26

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 26:1
verses.text: On Matthew.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 26:2
verses.text: Matt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 26:3
verses.text: vi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 26:4
verses.text: For this reason we are enjoined to ask what is sufficient for the preservation of the substance of the body: not luxury, but food, which restores what the body loses, and prevents death by hunger; not tables to inflame and drive on to pleasures, nor such things as make the body wax wanton against the soul; but bread, and that, too, not for a great number of years, but what is sufficient for us to-day.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:1
verses.text: On Luke.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:2
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:3
verses.text: ii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:4
verses.text: And if you please, we say that the Word was the first-born of God, who came down from heaven to the blessed Mary, and was made a first-born man in her womb, in order that the first-born of God might be manifested in union with a first-born man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:5
verses.text: When they brought Him to the temple to present Him to the Lord, they offered the oblations of purification.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:6
verses.text: For if the gifts of purification according to the law were offered for Him, in this indeed He was made under the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:7
verses.text: But the Word was not subject to the law in such wise as the sycophants fancy, since He is the law Himself; neither did God need sacrifices of purification, for He purifieth and sanctifieth all things at once in a moment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:8
verses.text: But though He took to Himself the frame of man as He received it from the Virgin, and was made under the law, and was thus purified after the manner of the first-born, it was not because He needed this ceremonial that He underwent its services, but only for the purpose of redeeming from the bondage of the law those who were sold under the judgment of the curse.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:9
verses.text: Chap.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:10
verses.text: xxiii For this reason the warders of Hades trembled when they saw Him; and the gates of brass and the bolts of iron were broken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:11
verses.text: For, lo, the Only-begotten entered, a soul among souls, God the Word with a (human) soul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:12
verses.text: For His body lay in the tomb, not emptied of divinity; but as, while in Hades, He was in essential being with His Father, so was He also in the body and in Hades.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:13
verses.text: For the Son is not contained in space, just as the Father; and He comprehends all things in Himself.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 27:14
verses.text: But of His own will he dwelt in a body animated by a soul, in order that with His soul He might enter Hades, and not with His pure divinity.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:1
verses.text: Doubtful Fragments on the Pentateuch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:2
verses.text: Preface.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:3
verses.text: In the name of the Father, and the Son, and the Holy Spirit, one God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:4
verses.text: This is a transcript of the excellent law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:5
verses.text: But before beginning to give the transcript of the book of the law, it will be worth while to instruct you, O brother, as to its excellence, and the dignity of its disposition.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:6
verses.text: Its first excellence is, that God delivered it by the hand of our most blessed ruler, the chief of the prophets, and first of the apostles, or those who were sent to the children of Israel, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:7
verses.text: , Moses the son of Amram, the son of Kohath, of the sons of Levi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:8
verses.text: Now he was adorned with all manner of wisdom, and endowed with the best genius.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:9
verses.text: Illustrious in dignity, remarkable for the integrity of his disposition, distinguished for power of reason, he talked with God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:10
verses.text: And He chose him as an instrument of value.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:11
verses.text: By His leader and prophet, God Most High sent it down to us, and committed it to us (blessed be His name) in the Syriac tongue of the Targum, which the Seventy translated into the Hebrew tongue, to wit, into the tongue of the nation, and the idiom of the common people.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:12
verses.text: Moses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:13
verses.text: therefore, received it from the eternal Lord, and was the first to whom it was entrusted, and who obeyed its rules and ordinances.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:14
verses.text: Then he taught it to the children of Israel, who also embraced it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:15
verses.text: And he explained to them its profound mysteries and dark places.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:16
verses.text: And he expounded to them those things which were less easy, as God permitted him, and concealed from them those secrets of the law, as God forbade him (to reveal them).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:17
verses.text: Nor did there rise among them one who was better practised in His judgments and decrees, and who communicated more clearly the mysteries of His doctrine, until God translated him to Himself, after He had made him perfect by forty whole years in the wilderness.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:18
verses.text: And these following are the names of the teachers who handed down the law in continuous succession after Moses the prophet, until the advent of Messiah:â  Know, then, my brother, whom may God bless, that God delivered the most excellent law into the hands of Moses the prophet, the son of Amram.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:19
verses.text: And Moses delivered it to Joshua the son of Nun.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:20
verses.text: And Joshua the son of Nun delivered it Anathal.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:21
verses.text: And Anathal delivered it to Jehud.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:22
verses.text: And Jehud delivered it to Samgar.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:23
verses.text: And Samgar delivered it to Baruk.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:24
verses.text: And Baruk delivered it to Gideon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:25
verses.text: And Gideon delivered it to Abimelech.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:26
verses.text: And Abimelech delivered it to Taleg.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:27
verses.text: And Taleg delivered it to Babin the Gileadite.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:28
verses.text: And Babin delivered it to Jiphtach.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:29
verses.text: And Jiphtach delivered it to Ephran.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:30
verses.text: And Ephran delivered it to Elul of the tribe Zebulon.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:31
verses.text: And Elul delivered it to Abdan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:32
verses.text: And Abdan delivered it to Shimshon the brave.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:33
verses.text: And Shimshon delivered it to Helkanah, the son of Jerachmu, the son of Jehud.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:34
verses.text: Moreover, he was the father of Samuel the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:35
verses.text: Of this Helkanah mention is made in the beginning of the first book of Kings (Samuel).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:36
verses.text: And Helkanah delivered it to Eli the priest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:37
verses.text: And Eli delivered it to Samuel the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:38
verses.text: And Samuel delivered it to Nathan the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:39
verses.text: And Nathan delivered it to Gad the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:40
verses.text: And Gad the prophet delivered it to Shemaiah the teacher.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:41
verses.text: And Shemaiah delivered it to Iddo the teacher.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:42
verses.text: And Iddo delivered it to Achia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:43
verses.text: And Achia delivered it to Abihu.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:44
verses.text: And Abihu delivered it to Elias the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:45
verses.text: And Elias delivered it to his disciple Elisaeus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:46
verses.text: And Elisaeus delivered it to Malachia the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:47
verses.text: And Malachia delivered it to Abdiahu.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:48
verses.text: And Abdiahu delivered it to Jehuda.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:49
verses.text: And Jehuda delivered it to Zacharias the teacher.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:50
verses.text: In those days came Bachthansar king of Babel, and laid waste the house of the sanctuary, and carried the children of Israel into captivity to Babel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:51
verses.text: And after the captivity of Babel, Zacharia the teacher delivered it to Esaia the prophet, the son of Amos.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:52
verses.text: And Esaia delivered it to Jeremia the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:53
verses.text: And Jeremia the prophet delivered it to Chizkiel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:54
verses.text: And Chizkiel the prophet delivered it to Hosea the prophet, the son of Bazi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:55
verses.text: And Hosea delivered it to Joiel the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:56
verses.text: And Joiel delivered it to Amos the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:57
verses.text: And Amos delivered it to Obadia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:58
verses.text: And Obadia delivered it to Jonan the prophet, the son of Mathi, the son of Armelah, who was the brother of Elias the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:59
verses.text: And Jonan delivered it to Micha the Morasthite, who delivered it to Nachum the Alcusite.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:60
verses.text: And Nachum delivered it to Chabakuk the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:61
verses.text: And Chabakuk delivered it to Sophonia the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:62
verses.text: And Sophonia delivered it to Chaggaeus the prophet.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:63
verses.text: And Chaggaeus delivered it to Zecharia the prophet, the son of Bershia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:64
verses.text: And Zecharia, when in captivity, delivered it to Malachia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:65
verses.text: And Malachia delivered it to Ezra the teacher.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:66
verses.text: And Ezra delivered it to Shamai the chief priest, and Jadua to Samean, (and) Samean delivered it to Antigonus.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:67
verses.text: And Antigonus delivered it to Joseph the son of Johezer, (and) Joseph the son of Gjuchanan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:68
verses.text: And Joseph delivered it to Jehosua, the son of Barachia.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:69
verses.text: And Jehosua delivered it to Nathan the Arbelite.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:70
verses.text: And Nathan delivered it to Shimeon, the elder son of Shebach.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:71
verses.text: This is he who carried the Messias in his arms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:72
verses.text: Simeon delivered it to Jehuda.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:73
verses.text: Jehuda delivered it to Zecharia the priest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:74
verses.text: And Zecharia the priest, the father of John the Baptist, delivered it to Joseph, a teacher of his own tribe.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:75
verses.text: And Joseph delivered it to Hanan and Caiaphas.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:76
verses.text: Moreover, from them were taken away the priestly, and kingly, and prophetic offices.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:77
verses.text: These were teachers at the advent of Messias; and they were both priests of the children of Israel.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:78
verses.text: Therefore the whole number of venerable and honourable priests put in trust of this most excellent law was fifty-six, Hanan (i-e:, Annas) and Caiaphas being excepted.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:79
verses.text: And those are they who delivered it in the last days to the state of the children of Israel; nor did there arise any priests after them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:80
verses.text: This is the account of what took place with regard to the most excellent law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:81
verses.text: Armius, author of the book of Times, has said: In the nineteenth year of the reign of King Ptolemy, He ordered the elders of the children of Israel to be assembled, in order that they might put into his hands a copy of the law, and that they might each be at hand to explain its meaning.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:82
verses.text: The elders accordingly came, bringing with them the most excellent law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:83
verses.text: Then he commanded that every one of them should interpret the book of the law to him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:84
verses.text: But he dissented from the interpretation which the elders had given.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:85
verses.text: And he ordered the elders to be thrust into prison and chains.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:86
verses.text: And seizing the book of the law, he threw it into a deep ditch, and cast fire and hot ashes upon it for seven days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:87
verses.text: Then afterwards he ordered them to throw the filth of the city into that ditch in which was the book of the law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:88
verses.text: And the ditch was filled to the very top.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:89
verses.text: The law remained seventy years under the filth in that ditch, yet did not perish, nor was there even a single leaf of it spoilt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:90
verses.text: In the twenty-first year of the reign of King Apianutus they took the book of the law out of the ditch, and not one leaf thereof was spoilt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:91
verses.text: And after the ascension of Christ into heaven, came King Titus, son of Aspasianus king of Rome, to Jerusalem, and besieged and took it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:92
verses.text: And he destroyed the edifice of the second house, which the children of Israel had built.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:93
verses.text: Titus the king destroyed the house of the sanctuary, and slew all the Jews who were in it, and built Tsion (sic) in their blood.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:94
verses.text: And after that deportation the Jews were scattered abroad in slavery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:95
verses.text: Nor did they assemble any more in the city of Jerusalem, nor is there hope anywhere of their returning.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:96
verses.text: After Jerusalem was laid waste, therefore, Shemaia and Antalia (Abtalion) delivered the law,âkings of Baalbach, a city which Soliman, son of King David, had built of old, and which was restored anew in the days of King Menasse, who sawed Esaia the prophet asunder.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:97
verses.text: King Adrian, of the children of Edom, besieged Baalbach, and took it, and slew all the Jews who were in it, (and) as many as were of the family of David he reduced to slavery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:98
verses.text: And the Jews were dispersed over the whole earth, as God Most High had foretold: "And I will scatter you among the Gentiles, and disperse you among the nations".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:99
verses.text: And these are the things which have reached us as to the history of that most excellent book.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 28:100
verses.text: The Preface is ended.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 29

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 29:1
verses.text: The Law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 29:2
verses.text: In the name of God eternal, everlasting, most mighty, merciful, compassionate.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 29:3
verses.text: By the help of God we begin to describe the book of the law, and its interpretation, as the holy, learned, and most excellent fathers have interpreted it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 29:4
verses.text: The following, therefore, is the interpretation of the first book, which indeed is the book of the creation (and) of created beings.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 30

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 30:1
verses.text: Of the Creation of Heaven and Earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 30:2
verses.text: "In the Beginning God Created," Etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 30:3
verses.text: An exposition of that which God said.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 30:4
verses.text: And the blessed prophet, indeed, the great Moses, wrote this book, and designated and marked it with the title, The Book of Being, i-e:, "of created beings," etc.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:1
verses.text: And the Lord Said: "And I Will Bring the Waters of the Flood Upon the Earth to Destroy All Flesh," Etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:2
verses.text: Hippolytus, the Targumist expositor, said:  The names of the wives of the sons of Noah are these: the name of the wife of Sem, Nahalath Mahnuk; and the name of the wife of Cham, Zedkat Nabu; and the name of the wife of Japheth, Arathka.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:3
verses.text: These, moreover, are their names in the Syriac Targum.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:4
verses.text: The name of the wife of Sem was Nahalath Mahnuk; the name of the wife of Cham, Zedkat Nabu; the name of the wife of Japheth, Arathka.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:5
verses.text: Therefore God gave intimation to Noah, and informed him of the coming of the flood, and of the destruction of the ruined (wicked).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:6
verses.text: And God Most High ordered him to descend from the holy mount, him and his sons, and the wives of his sons, and to build a ship of three storeys.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:7
verses.text: The lower storey was for fierce, wild, and dangerous beasts.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:8
verses.text: Between them there were stakes or wooden beams, to separate them from each other, and prevent them from having intercourse with each other.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:9
verses.text: The middle storey was for birds, and their different genera.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:10
verses.text: Then the upper storey was for Noah himself and his sonsâfor his own wife and his sons' wives.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:11
verses.text: Noah also made a door in the ship, on the east side.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:12
verses.text: He also constructed tanks of water, and store-rooms of provisions.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:13
verses.text: When he had made an end, accordingly, of building the ship, Noah, with his sons, Sem, Cham, and Japheth, entered the cave of deposits.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:14
verses.text: And on their first approach, indeed, they happily found the bodies of the fathers, Adam, Seth, Enosh, Kainan, Mahaliel, Jared, Mathusalach, and Lamech.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:15
verses.text: Those eight bodies were in the place of deposits, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:16
verses.text: , those of Adam, Seth, Enosh, Kainan, Mahaliel, Jared, Mathusalach, and Lamech.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:17
verses.text: Noah, moreover, took the body of Adam.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:18
verses.text: And his sons took with them offerings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:19
verses.text: Sem carried gold, Cham myrrh, and Japheth frankincense.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:20
verses.text: Then, leaving the cave of deposits, they transferred the offerings and the body of Adam to the holy mount.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:21
verses.text: And when they sat down by the body of Adam, over against paradise, they began to lament and weep for the loss of paradise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:22
verses.text: Then, descending from the holy mount, and lifting up their eyes towards paradise, they renewed their weeping and wailing, (and) uttered an eternal farewell in these terms: Farewell! peace to thee, O paradise of God! Farewell, O habitation of religion and purity! Farewell, O seat of pleasure and delight!  Then they embraced the stones and trees of the holy mount, and wept, and said:  Farewell, O habitation of the good! Farewell, O abode of holy bodies!  Then, after three days, Noah, with his sons and his sons' wives, came down from the holy mount to the base of the holy mount, to the ship's place.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:23
verses.text: For the (ark) was under the projecting edge of the holy mount.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:24
verses.text: And Noah entered the ship, and deposited the body of Adam, and the offerings, in the middle of the ship, upon a bier of wood, which he had prepared for the reception of the body.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:25
verses.text: And God charged Noah, saying: Make for thyself rattles of boxwood (or cypress).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:26
verses.text: Now ×¨××©××© is the wood called Sagh, i-e:, Indian plane.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:27
verses.text: Make also the hammer (bell) thereof of the same wood.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:28
verses.text: And the length of the rattle shall be three whole cubits, and its breadth one and a half cubit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:29
verses.text: And God enjoined him to strike the rattles three times every day, to wit, for the first time at early dawn, for the second time at mid-day, and for the third time at sunset.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:30
verses.text: And it happened that, as soon as Noah had struck the rattles, the sons of Cain and the sons of Vahim ran up straightway to him, and he warned and alarmed them by telling of the immediate approach of the flood, and of the destruction already hasting on and impending.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:31
verses.text: Thus, moreover, was the pity of God toward them displayed, that they might be converted and come to themselves again.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:32
verses.text: But the sons of Cain did not comply with what Noah proclaimed to them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 31:33
verses.text: And Noah brought together pairs, male and female, of all birds of every kind; and thus also of all beasts, tame and wild alike, pair and pair.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:1
verses.text: On Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:2
verses.text: vii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:3
verses.text: Hippolytus, the Syrian expositor of the Targum, has said: We find in an ancient Hebrew copy that God commanded Noah to range the wild beasts in order in the lower floor or storey, and to separate the males from the females by putting wooden stakes between them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:4
verses.text: And thus, too, he did with all the cattle, and also with the birds in the middle storey.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:5
verses.text: And God ordered the males thus to be separated from the females for the sake of decency and purity, lest they should perchance get intermingled with each other.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:6
verses.text: Moreover, God said to Moses: Provide victuals for yourself and your children.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:7
verses.text: And let them be of wheat, ground, pounded, kneaded with water, and dried.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:8
verses.text: And Noah there and then bade his wife, and his sons' wives, diligently attend to kneading dough and laying it in the oven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:9
verses.text: They kneaded dough accordingly, and prepared just about as much as might be sufficient for them, so that nothing should remain over but the very least.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:10
verses.text: And God charged Noah, saying to him:  Whosoever shall first announce to you the approach of the deluge, him you shall destroy that very moment.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:11
verses.text: In the meantime, moreover, the wife of Cham was standing by, about to put a large piece of bread into the oven.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:12
verses.text: And suddenly, according to the word of the Lord, water rushed forth from the oven, and the flow of water penetrated and destroyed the bread.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:13
verses.text: Therefore the wife of Cham exclaimed, addressing herself to Noah: Oh, sir, the word of God is come good: "that which God foretold is come to pass;" execute, therefore, that which the Lord commanded.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:14
verses.text: And when Noah heard the words of the wife of Chain, he said to her: Is then the flood already come? The wife of Cham said to him: Thou hast said it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:15
verses.text: God, however, suddenly charged Noah, saying:  Destroy not the wife of Cham; for from thy mouth is the beginning of destructionâ"thou didst first say, The flood is come".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:16
verses.text: At the voice of Noah the flood came, and suddenly the water destroyed that bread.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:17
verses.text: And the floodgates of heaven were opened, and the rains broke upon the earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:18
verses.text: And that same voice, in sooth, which had said of old, "Let the waters be gathered together into one place, and let the dry land appear," gave permission to the fountain of waters and the floods of the seas to break forth of their own accord, and brought out the waters.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:19
verses.text: Consider what God said about the world: Let all its high places be brought low, and they were brought low; and let its low places be raised from its depths.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:20
verses.text: And the earth was made bare and empty of all existence, as it was at the beginning.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:21
verses.text: And the rain descended from above, and the earth burst open beneath.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:22
verses.text: And the frame of the earth was destroyed, and its primitive order was broken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:23
verses.text: And the world became such as it was when desolated at the beginning by the waters which flowed over it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:24
verses.text: Nor was any one of the existences upon it left in its integrity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:25
verses.text: Its former structure went to wreck, and the earth was disfigured by the flood of waters that burst upon it, and by the magnitude of its inundations, and the multitude of showers, and the eruption from its depths, as the waters continually broke forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 32:26
verses.text: In fine, it was left such as it was formerly.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:1
verses.text: On Gen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:2
verses.text: viii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:3
verses.text: I  Hippolytus, the expositor of the Targum, and my master, Jacobus Rohaviensis, have said: On the twenty-seventh day of the month Jiar, which is the second Hebrew month, the ark rose from the base of the holy mount; and already the waters bore it, and it was carried upon them round about towards the four cardinal points of the world.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:4
verses.text: The ark accordingly held off from the holy mount towards the east, then returned towards the west, then turned to the south, and finally, bearing off eastwards, neared Mount Kardu on the first day of the tenth month.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:5
verses.text: And that is the second month Kanun.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:6
verses.text: And Noah came out of the ark on the twenty-seventh day of the month Jiar, in the second year: for the ark continued sailing five whole months, and moved to and fro upon the waters, and in a period of fifty-one days neared the land.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:7
verses.text: Nor thereafter did it float about any longer.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:8
verses.text: But it only moved successively toward the four cardinal points of the earth, and again finally stood toward the east.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:9
verses.text: We say, moreover, that that was a sign of the cross.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:10
verses.text: And the ark was a symbol of the Christ who was expected.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:11
verses.text: For that ark was the means of the salvation of Noah and his sons, and also of the cattle, the wild beasts, and the birds.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:12
verses.text: And Christ, too, when He suffered on the cross, delivered us from accusations and sins, and washed us in His own blood most pure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:13
verses.text: And just as the ark returned to the east, and neared Mount Kardu, so also Christ, when the work was accomplished and finished which He had proposed to Himself, returned to heaven to the bosom of His Father, and sat down upon the throne of His glory at the Father's right hand.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:14
verses.text: As to Mount Kardu, it is in the east, in the land of the sons of Raban, and the Orientals call it Mount Godash; the Arabians and Persians call it Ararat.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:15
verses.text: And there is a town of the name Kardu, and that hill is called after it, which is indeed very lofty and inaccessible, whose summit no one has ever been able to reach, on account of the violence of the winds and the storms which always prevail there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:16
verses.text: And if any one attempts to ascend it, there are demons that rush upon him, and cast him down headlong from the ridge of the mountain into the plain, so that he dies.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 33:17
verses.text: No one, moreover, knows what there is on the top of the mountain, except that certain relics of the wood of the ark still lie there on the surface of the top of the mountain.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:1
verses.text: On Deut.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:2
verses.text: xxxiii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:3
verses.text: II  Hippolytus, the expositor of the Targum, has said that Moses, when he had finished this prophecy, also pronounced a blessing upon all the children of Israel, by their several tribes, and prayed for them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:4
verses.text: Then God charged Moses, saying to him, Go up to Mount Nebo, which indeed is known by the name of the mount of the Hebrews, which is in the land of Moab over against Jericho.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:5
verses.text: And He said to him: View the land of Chanaan, which I am to give to the children of Israel for an inheritance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:6
verses.text: Thou, however, shalt never enter it; wherefore view it well from afar off.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:7
verses.text: When Moses therefore viewed it, he saw that land,âa land green, and abounding with all plenty and fertility, planted thickly with trees; and Moses was greatly moved, and wept.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:8
verses.text: And when Moses descended from Mount Nebo, he called for Joshua the son of Nun, and said to him before the children of Israel: Prevail, and be strong; for thou art to bring the children of Israel into the land which God promised to fathers that He would give their them for an inheritance.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:9
verses.text: Fear not, therefore, the people, neither be afraid of the nations: for God will be with thee.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:10
verses.text: And Moses wrote that Senna (Hebr.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:11
verses.text: ×× ×©× ="secondary law," or "Deuteronomy"), and gave it to the priests the sons of Levi, and commanded them, saying: For seven years keep this Senna hid, and show it not within the entire course of seven years.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:12
verses.text: ("And then") in the feast of tabernacles, the priests the sons of Levi will read this law before the children of Israel, that the whole people, men and women alike, may observe the words of God:  Command them to keep the word of God, which is in that law.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:13
verses.text: And whosoever shall violate one of its precepts, let him be accursed.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:14
verses.text: Accordingly, when Moses had finished the writing of the law, he gave it to Joshua the son of Nun, and enjoined him to give it to the sons of Levi, the priests.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:15
verses.text: Moses also enjoined and charged them to place the book of the law again within the ark of the covenant of the Lord, that it might remain there for a testimony for ever.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:16
verses.text: And when Moses had made an end of his injunctions, God bade him go up Mount Nebo, which is over against Jericho.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:17
verses.text: The Lord showed him the whole land of promise in its four quarters, from the wilderness to the sea, and from sea to sea.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:18
verses.text: And the Lord said to him, Thou hast seen it indeed with thine eyes, but thou shalt never enter it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:19
verses.text: There accordingly Moses died, the servant of God, by the command of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:20
verses.text: And the angels buried him on Mount Nebo, which is over against Beth-Phegor.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:21
verses.text: And no one knows of his sepulchre, even to this day.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:22
verses.text: For God concealed his grave.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:23
verses.text: And Moses lived  years; nor was his eye dim, nor was the skin of his face wrinkled.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:24
verses.text: Moses died on a certain day, at the third hour of the day, on the seventh day of the second month, which is the month Jiar.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:25
verses.text: And the children of Israel wept for him in the plains of Moab three days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:26
verses.text: And Joshua the sun of Nun was filled with the spirit of wisdom; for Moses had laid his hand upon him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:27
verses.text: And all the children of Israel obeyed him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:28
verses.text: And God charged Joshua the son of Nun on a certain day,ânamely, the seventh day of the month Nisan.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:29
verses.text: And Joshua the son of Nun lived  years, and died on the fourth day, which was the first day of the month Elul.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:30
verses.text: And they buried him in the city Thamnatserach, on Mount Ephraim.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 34:31
verses.text: Praise be to God for the completion of the work.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:1
verses.text: The Argument of the Exposition of the Psalms by Hippolytus, (Bishop) of Rome.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:2
verses.text: The book of Psalms contains new doctrine after the law which was given by Moses; and thus it is the second book of doctrine after the Scripture of Moses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:3
verses.text: After the death, then of Moses and Joshua, and after the judges, David arose, one deemed worthy to be called the father of the Saviour, and he was the first to give the Hebrews a new style of psalmody, by which he did away with the ordinances established by Moses with respect to sacrifice, and introduced a new mode of the worship of God by hymns and acclamations; and many other things also beyond the law of Moses he taught through his whole ministry.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:4
verses.text: And this is the sacredness of the book, and its utility.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:5
verses.text: And the account to be given of its inscription is this: (for) as most of the brethren who believe in Christ think that this book is David's, and inscribe it "Psalms of David," we must state what has reached us with respect to it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:6
verses.text: The Hebrews give the book the title "Sephra Thelim," and in the "Acts of the Apostles" it is called the "Book of Psalms" (the words are these, "as it is written in the Book of Psalms"), but the name (of the author) in the inscription of the book is not found there.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:7
verses.text: And the reason of that is, that the words written there are not the words of one man, but those of several together; Esdra, as tradition says, having collected in one volume, after the captivity, the psalms of several, or rather their words, as they are not all psalms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:8
verses.text: Thus the name of David is prefixed in the case of some, and that of Solomon in others, and that of Asaph in others.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:9
verses.text: There are some also that belong to Idithum (Jeduthun); and besides these there are others that belong to the sons of Core (Korah), and even to Moses.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:10
verses.text: As they are therefore the words of so many thus collected together, they could not be said by any one who understands the matter to be by David alone.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:11
verses.text: As regards those which have no inscription, we must also inquire to whom we ought to ascribe them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:12
verses.text: For why is it that even the simplest inscription is wanting in themâsuch as the one which runs thus, "A psalm of David," or "Of David," without any addition? Now, my idea is, that wherever this inscription occurs alone, what is written is neither a psalm nor a song, but some sort of utterance under guidance of the Holy Spirit, recorded for the behoof of him who is able to understand it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:13
verses.text: But the opinion of a certain Hebrew on these last matters has reached me, who held that, when there were many without any inscription, but preceded by one with the inscription "Of David," all these should be reckoned also to be by David.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:14
verses.text: And if this be the case, it follows that those without any inscription are by those (writers) who are rightly reckoned, according to the titles, to be the authors of the psalms preceding these.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:15
verses.text: This book of Psalms before us has also been called by the prophet the "Psalter," because, as they say, the psaltery alone among musical instruments gives back the sound from above when the brass is struck, and not from beneath, after the manner of others.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:16
verses.text: In order, therefore, that those who understand it may be zealous to carry out the analogy of such an appellation, and may also look above, from which direction its melody comesâfor this reason he has styled it the Psalter.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:17
verses.text: For it is entirely the voice and utterance of the most Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:18
verses.text: Let us inquire, further, why there are one hundred and fifty psalms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:19
verses.text: That the number fifty is sacred, is manifest from the days of the celebrated festival of Pentecost, which indicates release from labours, and (the possession of) joy.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:20
verses.text: For which reason neither fasting nor bending the knee is decreed for those days.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:21
verses.text: For this is a symbol of the great assembly that is reserved for future times.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:22
verses.text: Of which times there was a shadow in the land of Israel in the year called among the Hebrews "Jobel" (Jubilee), which is the fiftieth year in number, and brings with it liberty for the slave, and release from debt, and the like.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:23
verses.text: And the holy Gospel knows also the remission of the number fifty, and of that number which is cognate with it, and stands by it, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:24
verses.text: , five hundred; for it is not without a purpose that we have given us there the remission of fifty pence and of five hundred.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:25
verses.text: Thus, then, it was also meet that the hymns to God on account of the destruction of enemies, and in thanksgiving for the goodness of God, should contain not simply one set of fifty, but three such, for the name of Father, and Son, and Holy Spirit.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:26
verses.text: The number fifty, moreover, contains seven sevens, or a Sabbath of Sabbaths; and also over and above these full Sabbaths, a new beginning, in the eight, of a really new rest that remains above the Sabbaths.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:27
verses.text: And let any one who is able, observe this (as it is carried out) in the Psalms with more, indeed, than human accuracy, so as to find out the reasons in each case, as we shall set them forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:28
verses.text: Thus, for instance, it is not without a purpose that the eighth psalm has the inscription, "On the wine-presses," as it comprehends the perfection of fruits in the eight; for the time for the enjoyment of the fruits of the true vine could not be before the eight.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:29
verses.text: And again, the second psalm inscribed "On the wine-presses," is the eightieth, containing another eighth number, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:30
verses.text: , in the tenth multiple.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:31
verses.text: The eighty-third, again, is made up by the union of two holy numbers, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:32
verses.text: , the eight in the tenth multiple, and the three in the first multiple.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:33
verses.text: And the fiftieth psalm is a prayer for the remission of sins, and a confession.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:34
verses.text: For as, according to the Gospel, the fiftieth obtained remission, confirming thereby that understanding of the jubilee, so he who offers up such petitions in full confession hopes to gain remission in no other number than the fiftieth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:35
verses.text: And again, there are also certain others which are called "Songs of degrees," in number fifteen, as was also the number of the steps of the temple, and which show thereby, perhaps, that the "steps" (or "degrees") are comprehended within the number seven and the number eight.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:36
verses.text: And these songs of degrees begin after the one hundred and twentieth psalm, which is called simply "a psalm," as the more accurate copies give it.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:37
verses.text: And this is the number of the perfection of the life of man.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:38
verses.text: And the hundredth psalm, which begins thus, "I will sing of mercy and judgment, O Lord," embraces the life of the saint in fellowship with God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:39
verses.text: And the one hundred and fiftieth ends with these words, "Let every thing that hath breath praise the Lord".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:40
verses.text: But since, as we have already said, to do this in the case of each, and to find out the reasons, is very difficult, and too much for human nature to accomplish, we shall content ourselves with these things by way of an outline.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:41
verses.text: Only let us add this, that the psalms which deal with historical matter are not found in regular historical order.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:42
verses.text: And the only reason for this is to be found in the numbers according to which the psalms are arranged.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:43
verses.text: For instance, the history in the fifty-first is antecedent to the history in the fiftieth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:44
verses.text: For everybody acknowledges that the matter of Doeg the Idumean calumniating David to Saul is antecedent to the sin with the wife of Urias; yet it is not without good reason that the history which should be second is placed first, since, as we have before said, the place regarding remission has an affinity with the number fifty.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:45
verses.text: He, therefore, who is not worthy of remission, passes the number fifty, as Doeg the Idumean.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:46
verses.text: For the fifty-first is the psalm that treats of him.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:47
verses.text: And, moreover, the third is in the same position, since it was written when David fled from the face of Absalom his son; and thus, as all know who read the books of Kings, it should come properly after the fifty-first and the fiftieth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:48
verses.text: And if any one desires to give further attention to these and such like matters, he will find more exact explanations of the history for himself, as well as of the inscriptions and the order of the psalms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:49
verses.text: It is likely, also, that a similar account is to be given of the fact, that David alone of the prophets prophesied with an instrument, called by the Greeks the "psaltery," and by the Hebrews the "nabla," which is the only musical instrument that is quite straight, and has no curve.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:50
verses.text: And the sound does not come from the lower parts, as is the case with the lute and certain other instruments, but from the upper.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:51
verses.text: For in the lute and the lyre the brass when struck gives back the sound from beneath.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:52
verses.text: But this psaltery has the source of its musical numbers above, in order that we, too, may practise seeking things above, and not suffer ourselves to be borne down by the pleasure of melody to the passions of the flesh.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:53
verses.text: And I think that this truth, too, was signified deeply and clearly to us in a prophetic way in the construction of the instrument, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:54
verses.text: , that those who have souls well ordered and trained, have the way ready to things above.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:55
verses.text: And again, an instrument having the source of its melodious sound in its upper parts, may be taken as like the body of Christ and His saintsâthe only instrument that maintains rectitude; "for He did no sin, neither was guile found in his mouth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:56
verses.text: This is indeed an instrument, harmonious, melodious, well-ordered, that took in no human discord, and did nothing out of measure, but maintained in all things, as it were, harmony towards the Father; for, as He says: "He that is of the earth is earthly, and speaketh of the earth: He that cometh from heaven, testifies of what He has seen and heard".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:57
verses.text: As there are "psalms," and "songs," and "psalms of song," and "songs of psalmody," it remains that we discuss the difference between these.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:58
verses.text: We think, then, that the "psalms" are those which are simply played to an instrument, without the accompaniment of the voice, and (which are composed) for the musical melody of the instrument; and that those are called "songs" which are rendered by the voice in concert with the music; and that they are called "psalms of song" when the voice takes the lead, while the appropriate sound is also made to accompany it, rendered harmoniously by the instruments; and "songs of psalmody," when the instrument takes the lead, while the voice has the second place, and accompanies the music of the strings.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:59
verses.text: And thus much as to the letter of what is signified by these terms.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:60
verses.text: But as to the mystical interpretation, it would be a "psalm" when, by smiting the instrument, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:61
verses.text: , the body, with good deeds we succeed in good action though not wholly proficient in speculation; and a "song," when, by revolving the mysteries of the truth, apart from the practical, and assenting fully to them, we have the noblest thoughts of God and His oracles, while knowledge enlightens us, and wisdom shines brightly in our souls; and a "song of psalmody," when, while good action takes the lead, according to the word, "If thou desire wisdom, keep the commandments, and the Lord shall give her unto thee," we understand wisdom at the same time, and are deemed worthy by God to know the truth of things, till now kept hid from us; and a "psalm of song," when, by revolving with the light of wisdom some of the more abstruse questions pertaining to morals, we first become prudent in action, and then also able to tell what, and when, and how action is to be taken.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:62
verses.text: And perhaps this is the reason why the first inscriptions nowhere contain the word "songs," but only "psalm" or "psalms;" for the saint does not begin with speculation; but when he has become in a simple way a believer, according to orthodoxy, he devotes himself to the actions that are to be done.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:63
verses.text: For this reason, also, are there many "songs" at the end; and wherever there is the word "degrees," there we do not find the word "psalm," whether by itself alone or with any addition, but only "songs".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:64
verses.text: For in the "degrees" (or "ascents"), the saints will be engaged in nothing but in speculation alone.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:65
verses.text: And let the account which we have offered, following the indications given in the interpretation of the Seventy, suffice for this subject in general.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:66
verses.text: But again, as we found in the Seventy, and in Theodotion, and in Symmachus, in some psalms, and these not a few, the word Î´Î¹á½±ÏÎ±Î»Î¼Î± inserted, we endeavoured to make out whether those who placed it there meant to mark a change at those places in rhythm or melody, or any alteration in the mode of instruction, or in thought, or in force of language.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:67
verses.text: It is found, however, neither in Aquila nor in the Hebrew; but there, instead of Î´Î¹á½±ÏÎ±Î»Î¼Î± (= an intervening musical symphony), we find the word á¼Îµá½· (= ever).

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:68
verses.text: And further, let not this fact escape thee, O man of learning, that the Hebrews also divided the Psalter into five books, so that it might be another Pentateuch.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:69
verses.text: For from Ps.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:70
verses.text: i.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:71
verses.text: to xl.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:72
verses.text: they reckoned one book; and from xli.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:73
verses.text: to lxxi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:74
verses.text: they reckoned a second; and from lxxii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:75
verses.text: to lxxxviii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:76
verses.text: they counted a third book; and from lxxxix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:77
verses.text: to cv.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:78
verses.text: a fourth; and from cvi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:79
verses.text: to cl.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:80
verses.text: they made up the fifth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:81
verses.text: For they judged that each psalm closing with the words, "Blessed be the Lord, Amen, amen," formed the conclusion of a book.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:82
verses.text: And in them we have "prayer," viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:83
verses.text: , supplication offered to God for anything requisite; and the "vow," i-e:, engagement; and the "hymn," which is the song of blessing to God for benefits enjoyed; and "praise" or "extolling," which is the laudation of the wonders of God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:84
verses.text: For laudation is nothing else but just the superlative of praise.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:85
verses.text: However it may be with the "time when and the manner" in which this idea of the Psalms has hit upon by the inspired David, he at least seems to have been the first, and indeed the only one, concerned in it, and that, too, at the earliest period, when he taught his fingers to tune the psaltery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:86
verses.text: For if any other before him showed the use of the psaltery and lute, it was at any rate in a very different way that such an one did it, only putting together some rude and clumsy contrivance, or simply employing the instrument, without singing either to melody or to words, but only amusing himself with a rude sort of pleasure.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:87
verses.text: But after such he was the first to reduce the affair to rhythm, and order, and art, and also to wed the singing of the song with the melody.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:88
verses.text: And, what is of greater importance, this most inspired of men sang to God, or of God, beginning in this wise even at the period when he was among the shepherds and youths in a simpler and humbler style, and afterwards when he became a man and a king, attempting something loftier and of more public interest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:89
verses.text: And he is said to have made this advance, especially after he had brought back the ark into the city.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:90
verses.text: At that time he often danced before the ark, and often sang songs of thanksgiving and songs to celebrate its recovery.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:91
verses.text: And then by and by, allocating the whole tribe of the Levites to the duty, he appointed four leaders of the choirs, viz.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:92
verses.text: , Asaph, Aman (Heman), Ethan, and Idithum (Jeduthun), inasmuch as there are also in all things visible four primal principles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:93
verses.text: And he then formed choirs of men, selected from the rest.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:94
verses.text: And he fixed their number at seventy-two, having respect, I think, to the number of the tongues that were confused, or rather divided, at the time of the building of the tower.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 35:95
verses.text: And what was typified by this, but that hereafter all tongues shall again unite in one common confession, when the Word takes possession of the whole world?.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 36

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 36:1
verses.text: On Psalm xxxi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 36:2
verses.text: Of the Triumph of the Christian Faith.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 36:3
verses.text: The mercy of God is not so "marvellous" when it is shown in humbler cities as when it is shown in "a strong city," and for this reason "God is to be blessed".

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 37

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 37:1
verses.text: III.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 37:2
verses.text: On Psalm lv.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 37:3
verses.text: One of old used to say that those only descend alive into Hades who are instructed in the knowledge of things divine; for he who has not tasted of the words of life is dead.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38:1
verses.text: On Psalm lviii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38:2
verses.text: But since there is a time when the righteous shall rejoice, and sinners shall meet the end foretold for them, we must with all reason fully acknowledge and declare that God is inspector and overseer of all that is done among men, and judges all who dwell upon earth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38:3
verses.text: It is proper further to inquire whether the prophecy in hand, which quite corresponds and fits in with those preceding it, may describe the end.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38:4
verses.text: When Hippolytus dictated these words, the grammarian asked him why he hesitated about that prophecy, as if he mistrusted the divine power in that calamity of exile.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38:5
verses.text: The learned man calls attention to the question why the word Î´Î¹Î±Î³Ïá½±Ïá¿ (= may describe) was used by me in the subjunctive mood, as if silently indicating doubt.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38:6
verses.text: Hippolytus accordingly replied:â  You know indeed quite well, that words of that form are used as conveying by implication a rebuke to those who study the prophecies about Christ, and talk righteousness with the mouth, while they do not admit His coming, nor listen to His voice when He calls to them, and says, "He that hath ears to hear let him hear;" who have made themselves like the serpent and have made their ears like those of a deaf viper, and so forth.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 38:7
verses.text: God then does, in truth, take care of the righteous, and judges their cause when injured on the earth; and He punishes those who dare to injure them.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:1
verses.text: On Psalm lix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:2
verses.text: Concerning the Jews.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:3
verses.text: For this reason, even up to our day, though they see the boundaries (of their country), and go round about them, they stand afar off.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:4
verses.text: And therefore have they no longer king or high priest or prophet, nor even scribes and Pharisees and Sadducees among them.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:5
verses.text: He does not, however, say that they are to be cut off; wherefore their race still subsists, and the succession of their children is continued.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:6
verses.text: For they have not been cut off nor consumed from among menâbut they are and exist stillâyet only as those who have been rejected and cast down from the honour of which of old they were deemed worthy by God.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:7
verses.text: But again, "Scatter them," he says, "by Thy power;" which word has also come to pass.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:8
verses.text: For they are scattered throughout the whole earth, in servitude everywhere, and engaging in the lowest and most servile occupations, and doing any unseemly work for hunger's sake.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:9
verses.text: For if they were destroyed from among men, and remained nowhere among the living, they could not see my people, he means, nor know my Church in its prosperity.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:10
verses.text: Therefore "scatter" them everywhere on earth, where my Church is to be established, in order that when they see the Church founded by me, they may be roused to emulate it in piety.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 39:11
verses.text: And these things did the Saviour also ask on their behalf.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 40

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 40:1
verses.text: On Psalm lxii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 40:2
verses.text: Aliens (Î¼ÎµÏÎ±Î½á½±ÏÏÎ±Î¹) properly so called are those who have been despoiled by some enemies or adversaries, and have then become wanderers; a thing which we indeed also endured formerly at the hand of the demons.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 40:3
verses.text: But from the time that Christ took us up by faith in Him, we are no longer aliens from the true countryâthe Jerusalem which is aboveânor have we to bear alienation in error from the truth.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 41

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 41:1
verses.text: On Psalm lxviii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 41:2
verses.text: Of the Enlargement of the Church.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 41:3
verses.text: And the unbelieving, too, He sometimes draws by means of sickness and outward circumstances; yea, many also by means of visions have come to make their abode with Jesus.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 42

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 42:1
verses.text: On Psalm lxxxix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 42:2
verses.text: Of the Gentiles.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 42:3
verses.text: And around us are the wise men of the Greeks mocking and jeering us, as those who believe without inquiry, and foolishly.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 43:1
verses.text: On the Words in Psalm xcvi.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 43:2
verses.text: : "Let the Sea Roar (Be Moved), and the Fulness Thereof".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 43:3
verses.text: By these words it is signified that the preaching of the Gospel will be spread abroad over the seas and the islands in the ocean, and among the people dwelling therein, who are here called "the fulness thereof".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 43:4
verses.text: And that word has been made good.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 43:5
verses.text: For churches of Christ fill all the islands, and are being multiplied every day, and the teaching of the Word of salvation is gaining accessions.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 44

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 44:1
verses.text: On Psalm cxix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 44:2
verses.text: â  He who loves truth, and never utters a false word with his mouth, may say, "I have chosen the way of truth".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 44:3
verses.text: Moreover, he who always sets the judgments of God before his eyes, and remembers them in every action, will say, "Thy judgments have I not forgotten".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 44:4
verses.text: And how is our heart enlarged by trials and afflictions! For these pluck out the thorns of anxious thoughts within us, and enlarge the heart for the reception of the divine laws.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 44:5
verses.text: For, says he, "in affliction Thou hast enlarged me".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 44:6
verses.text: Then do we walk in the way of God's commandments, well prepared for it by the endurance of trials.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 45

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 45:1
verses.text: On the Words in Psalm cxxvii.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 45:2
verses.text: : "On the Wrath of Mine Enemies".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 45:3
verses.text: Etc.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 45:4
verses.text: Hast thou seen that the power (of God) is most mighty on every side? For (says he) Thou wilt be able to save me when in the midst of troubles, and to keep them in check when they rage, and rave, and breathe fire.

chapters.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 46

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 46:1
verses.text: On the Words in Psalm cxxxix.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 46:2
verses.text: : "My Substance or (Bones) Was Not Hid from Thee, Which Thou Madest in Secret".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 46:3
verses.text: It is said also by those who treat of the nature and generation of animals, that the change of the blood into bone is something invisible and intangible, although in the case of other parts, I mean the flesh and nerves, the mode of their formation may be seen.

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 46:4
verses.text: And the Scripture also, in Ecclesiastes, adduces this, saying, "As thou knowest not the bones in the womb of her that is with child, so thou shalt not know the works of God".

verses.name: Hippolytus: Extant Works and Fragments, Exegetical 46:5
verses.text: But from Thee was not hid even my substance, as it was originally in the lowest parts of the earth.
